McIlvanney, who became an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University, later became a full-time writer, earning the title of "Godfather of Tartan Noir" with his acclaimed Laidlaw trilogy and other works. He was also a poet, journalist, broadcaster, and contributed to political and sporting life in Scotland. McIlvanney passed away on 5 December in his Glasgow home.

An evacuation and safety measures were implemented in a town near a swimming pool due to a suspected British sea mine from the 1940s or 1950s, affecting three streets and causing disruptions to ferry services. The mine was moved to a safer location for further handling.

UK Sport has cut funding for badminton by over £4m, reducing its budget to £25.98m, while also reducing the overall investment in Olympic and Paralympic sports by £2m from the record £347m set for the Rio Games. The cuts have led to a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals for Team GB in Tokyo 2020. Despite the cuts, the government has confirmed its commitment to funding Tokyo 2020. The decision to cut funding for badminton, which had a target of winning a medal in Rio, has been described as "catastrophic" by the sport's chief executive. Other sports like judo have seen slight funding increases, while sports such as basketball, handball, and volleyball have had their funding withdrawn in previous years. UK Sport has not yet confirmed the final investment for the five Olympic sports and two Paralympic sports added for Tokyo 2020, with £9m of the £345m total still to be allocated.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff, a designated conservation area, will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel, two assisted-living apartment blocks, and a 90-room hotel. The East Cliff Project LLP will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The council received 246 letters supporting the plans, but 49 residents and the Ancient Monuments Society objected, stating the development would harm the area's historic character. English Heritage also strongly objected to the scale of the development.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, was attacked and beaten by Jake Vallely, 24, while off-duty in Brecon. Vallely, who was on a seven-hour drinking binge and boasted of being the "hardest man in Brecon," was sentenced to be sentenced on 8 December. Vallely's friend, Aaeron Evans, was cleared of manslaughter charges as he was not present during the attack. The incident occurred outside a bar called The Cellar, and Vallely fled the scene after the attack. The community of Brecon was shocked by the incident, and a family tribute described Pte Boyd as a loving, caring, and loyal individual with a promising career ahead of him.

Andrew Travers left his position as Barnet's chief executive by mutual agreement after an error led to voters being turned away from polling stations due to missing names on the poll list. An independent investigation has been launched, and Deputy chief executive John Hooton will temporarily take over. The council apologized and offered emergency proxy votes, but voters questioned the fairness of the results. The council's review of the situation, including the EU Referendum arrangements, will conclude by the end of May.

Gateshead won 2-1 against Wrexham, with goals from Josh Gillies and Ryan Bowman, while Wrexham's only goal came from a fine free-kick by Cameron Belford. The match saw both teams having chances, with Wrexham's second half being less effective. Key players included Josh Gillies, Ryan Bowman, and Sean Newton for Gateshead, and Cameron Belford, Sean Newton, and Joel Logan for Wrexham. Wrexham made several substitutions, including Lee Fowler and Jamal Fyfield.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 evaluates the social and economic welfare of individuals over 60 in 96 countries, ranking Norway as the best and Afghanistan as the worst.

The OneWeb project aims to create a constellation of at least 600 spacecraft, potentially expanding to over 2,000, to provide global broadband access, including to schools. Airbus, Europe's largest space company, is collaborating with OneWeb to develop new, cost-effective manufacturing methods, with the first assembly line in Toulouse, France, and a second in Florida. The project plans to launch the first 10 satellites in April, followed by more in subsequent months, with a total of over 800 satellites by mid-decade. The UK Space Agency will oversee regulatory compliance, including debris mitigation, as OneWeb is registered in the UK's Channel Islands. The project has raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional loans. OneWeb aims to set new standards in debris mitigation, with a commitment to de-orbit satellites within two years. The success of these new manufacturing approaches could disrupt the satellite industry, but bespoke treatments will still be needed for certain applications.

Mr. Swinney criticized the UK government's spending review, claiming it has placed "unprecedented pressure" on Scotland's public expenditure, with a projected 12.5% reduction in the discretionary budget by 2019-20 compared to 2010-11. He stated that 4.2% of this reduction would occur between now and 2019-20, and that the UK government has imposed real terms cuts on Scotland every year until 2020, with over £1bn still to come. Mr. Swinney emphasized that schools, hospitals, and the police service would not be sacrificed, and that the Scottish government would defend key priorities. In response, the UK government's Scotland Office highlighted that Scotland would have £390m more spending available next year, and that the block grant would be almost £30bn. Labour's Jackie Baillie called for a long-term budget and a real alternative to austerity.

The passage discusses the challenges faced by people with severe disabilities and their families when accessing ordinary accessible toilets, highlighting the need for Changing Places toilets with enhanced facilities. Campaigners, including Lorna Fillingham, are advocating for these toilets to be made compulsory in larger buildings. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, which are larger and more accommodating than standard accessible toilets. The passage also mentions the positive impact of such facilities, as seen with Arsenal Football Club, and the importance of making these toilets a compulsory requirement in new constructions to ensure accessibility for all.

A group of Italian consumer organizations has filed a formal complaint with the European Commission, accusing McDonald's of imposing excessive rents and fees on its franchisees, preventing them from switching to competitors due to long contracts, and leasing premises at above market rates, which allegedly leads to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. The Service Employees International Union (SEIU) and European unions are supporting the complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate. McDonald's defends its practices, stating it shares risks and rewards with its franchisees. The European Commission will now study the submission. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, and McDonald's received $9.27bn in revenues from its franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh, initiated by Bangor Elim Church in support of 13-year-old Joshua Martin from Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer, has gone viral. The campaign, which started on Facebook and Instagram, has led to a massive billboard appearing in Holywood, funded by an anonymous donor, and has garnered global support, with Joshua's classmates also using the hashtag.

Brecon Barracks, a historic military site in Brecon, Wales, is set to close in 2024 as part of a UK military restructuring, despite its long history and significance, including being home to troops who fought the Zulus at Rorke's Drift. Conservative MP Chris Davies, who condemned the closure, launched a petition against it, citing the barracks' role in military history and its impact on the local economy, including a thriving military tourism industry. The closure is part of a broader reorganization in Wales, which will also see the closure of Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. The Defence Secretary defended the decision, stating it would create a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. Shadow Defence Secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the ministry's right to restructure but warned of the negative impact on people's livelihoods.

The House of Lords report highlights the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit, noting that while the industry contributes minimally to GDP and employment, it should not be marginalized in Brexit negotiations. The report suggests that the UK may need to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters and retain elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, including quotas based on scientific advice. The report also raises concerns about potential different fisheries management regimes in the UK and the need for continued market access. Despite these concerns, the industry sees Brexit as an opportunity for better control and sustainable management, with recent EU quota increases seen as positive. The UK government aims to ensure maximum trade freedom with the single market while reviewing fisheries management.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA worker, revealed the extent of US surveillance, including access to chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, and social networking data, through documents he leaked. The NSA, with the help of Prism, gained backdoor access to servers of major tech companies, raising concerns about privacy and the legality of such actions, as well as the implications for internet use and data protection laws.

The venture, backed by Tesla Motors, SpaceX CEO Elon Musk, Paypal co-founder Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, aims to advance AI for positive human impact, with only a small portion of the $1bn pledged to be spent in the next few years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a man seriously injured in a 2006 bomb attack in Afghanistan, has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook since carrying the Olympic torch on 26 June. Despite Facebook's limit of 5,000 friends per page, he has been overwhelmed by the support, with his page receiving 19,000 hits on an update alone. He spends his time in the gym, rehab, and raising money for military charities and as a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. His mother, Diane, expressed amazement at the support, with some mail addressed directly to him. Facebook suggested he consider having a page instead of a profile due to the high number of friend requests, or using the subscribe feature. A total of 8,000 people will carry the Olympic torch on its journey to the London Games.

In 2011, the poverty rate in the US remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty, and the real median income of households decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, measured by the Gini index, increased by 1.6% for the first time since 1993. The percentage of Americans without health insurance dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%. In 2010, US poverty reached a record high of 15.1%.

The 25-year-old cricketer, who moved to the Red Rose from Somerset in 2013, is tied to the club until 2019. He is a short-format specialist who has scored England's three fastest ODI centuries, including a 46-ball ton against Pakistan. Ashley Giles, the cricket director and head coach, praised him as one of the most talented cricketers in the game and noted his positive impact on the team. Buttler, who has also played in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will return to Lancashire for Friday's T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with no preservation proposals submitted. Bidders are finalizing their bids for the sale, with viewings in late February and March, and a decision expected in spring. The government's Disposal Services Authority aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the industry's capacity. Conservative MP Penny Mordaunt expressed a preference for a reef and diving attraction, while the Ministry of Defence seeks the best financial return for taxpayers. The Type 22 frigates, originally anti-submarine ships, evolved into powerful surface combatants with a crew of about 280. Last year, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for scrap for £3m.

Racial and political tensions in Fiji, stemming from a series of coups since 1987, have led to economic harm, international isolation, and a divided society between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. The country has experienced four coups in 20 years, with the most recent in 2006, and has faced suspension from the Commonwealth. Despite these challenges, Fiji has held free elections in 2014, leading to the restoration of full diplomatic ties with Australia and New Zealand, and re-admittance to the Commonwealth. The economy, reliant on sugar, tourism, and mining, is diverse but hampered by trade and budget deficits, making Fiji a significant recipient of aid.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. He mentioned that two shipments of weapons were attacked on their way to the port of Latakia, with the second shipment intercepted by terrorist groups. Al-Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements in the country. The Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that rebels now control the prison, which holds at least 3,000 detainees. Russia, a key ally of Syria, urged Damascus to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by 1 March. The OPCW has admitted that the destruction process has been slowed down by security concerns.

The Booker Prize shortlist for 2013 includes Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others," Howard Jacobson's "J," Ali Smith's "How To Be Both," Joshua Ferris's "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour," Karen Joy Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves," and Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North." The prize, open to all English-language authors, will be announced at London's Guildhall. The winner will receive £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book. The judging panel for the 46th year of the Booker Prize includes AC Grayling, Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven, and Erica Wagner. The ceremony will be covered by the BBC News Channel and BBC Arts.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will now hear arguments about whether to grant the appeal and decide if it should be "allowed or dismissed". An interim injunction will remain in place until the end of the hearing. PJS, who has young children and a spouse in the public eye, argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action against the Sun On Sunday, which wants to publish an account of alleged extra-marital activities. The Sun On Sunday had previously been prevented from identifying PJS in publications in England and Wales by two appeal court judges. However, the Sun On Sunday argued that stories had been published in the US, Scotland, and elsewhere where the injunction does not apply. PJS opposed lifting the ban, stating that the confidentiality of the allegations had probably been lost. The man's solicitors had been monitoring the internet and removing stories in breach of the injunction, but the judges said it was now a "hopeless task".

Fosse Park, a property near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased in August for £345.5m. The new owners are planning to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of the units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the new owners have met with the council to address potential planning questions. Paul Clarke, director of investments at Crown Estates, emphasized the need to address parking and congestion issues, as well as the quality of common areas and facilities. The goal is to enhance the overall quality of Fosse Park.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the film, leading to its release being postponed for content review. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, but the new release date has not been announced. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification" and local cinema chains are offering refunds for advance ticket purchases. The decision to review the film has been criticized on social media, with some netizens calling it "stupid and laughable." The film's director, Bill Condon, has discussed the "exclusively gay moment" involving LeFou, the sidekick of Gaston, who grapples with feelings for him. Despite the controversy, the Malaysian tourism minister has criticized the ban as "ridiculous."

Landlords in Southampton must apply for a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence if they let properties to more than three unrelated people, despite the cost of £1,000 and the risk of a £20,000 fine. The council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area, with tenants often fearing eviction and living in poorly maintained properties. The licensing affects properties in several designated areas, and the council has prosecuted a few for non-compliance.

Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and Micheál Martin of Fianna Fáil aim to prevent a second election, with Martin's party willing to support a minority government but not a full programme. Water charges are a major issue, with proposals including a commission to review Irish Water's future. Fianna Fáil wants to abolish water charges immediately, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. After the election, no party formed a majority, and TDs have yet to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, a ship owned by Italian company Atlantica di Navigazione, was traveling to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of its car decks, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire, which started on a Tuesday afternoon, quickly got out of control, leading to the evacuation of passengers and crew onto lifeboats. At least three people were injured and taken to hospital by helicopter, with one reported to be seriously hurt. Several ships, including two passenger ferries, were sent to assist, and the passengers eventually boarded the Puglia ferry, which was en route back to Palma de Mallorca. Spanish officials indicated that the Sorrento may sink due to the fire, and psychologists were being asked to provide counseling at the port. The ferry sent out distress signals at 13:50 local time.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs identified double voting, including by students, and suggested better integration of individual electoral registers to prevent duplicates. A record 46.8 million people registered to vote in the 8 June election, with 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. Concerns over duplicate applications, which were more common after the EU referendum, persist due to a lack of direct communication between electoral registers and the online registration service. The watchdog recommended clearer registration information and a verification function, similar to those in Australia, New Zealand, and Ireland. Despite efforts to inform people about poll cards and local council elections, many still registered twice, leading to administrative burdens. The watchdog urged people to report double voting, which is a criminal offence, and called for better cross-checking of electoral registers to prevent it. Labour's Cat Smith warned against making it harder for young people to register, emphasizing the need for resources to prosecute double voting.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL star and University of Nebraska player, is believed to have committed suicide. He had a troubled career and life, including multiple convictions for assault, and was serving a prison sentence when he allegedly killed his former cellmate, Damion Soward. A judge has found enough evidence to try him for Soward's death, but it is unclear how Phillips took his own life. His former coach, Tom Osborne, described him as an intelligent person with good qualities but also anger issues.

Private Derby XXX, a mascot ram of the Mercian Regiment, was promoted to lance corporal for "good behaviour" at an eight-year celebration event in Chester. The promotion was awarded by Brigadier Andrew Williams. Derby is the 30th mascot in a line dating back to the Indian Mutiny War. Acquired in 1858, he became the mascot of the Mercian Regiment in 2007. Lance Corporal Derby joined the regiment in 2014, has an army number, is paid for rations, and takes holidays on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also helped with Christmas lights in Ashbourne and met Prince William at a 1914 Christmas Truce memorial unveiling.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory over Borussia Dortmund, moving closer to a Champions League spot, with Dejan Lovren scoring in injury time. The win, under Jurgen Klopp's leadership, marked a transition from doubt to belief among fans, inspired by Klopp's touchline demeanor and the team's resilience. The match featured a dramatic turnaround, with goals from Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho, and Lovren, against a backdrop of intense emotions and a memorable pre-match atmosphere. The victory was seen as a testament to Klopp's influence on the team and a step towards future successes, including a potential return to the Champions League.

The EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee meeting in London saw Mr. Davis commit to keeping Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit negotiations, with monthly meetings for a "two-way information flow." Mr. Russell called for greater transparency from the UK government regarding its strategic intentions, particularly concerning EU market access, and emphasized the importance of the single market for Scotland's economic prosperity. The UK government anticipates the High Court's Article 50 judgment to be overturned on appeal, with the Scottish government planning to oppose the UK in the Supreme Court.

Dr. Sandra Corr conducts a physical examination on Daisy, a cloned sheep, to check for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. Daisy is one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham, all of whom are considered identical twins to Dolly the sheep. The study, led by Prof. Kevin Sinclair, investigates whether cloned animals age normally and if they are healthier than non-cloned animals. The research includes joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, focusing on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. The results, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published next week. Currently, the cloned sheep appear to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden's horse Shutter Speed won the race, beating the favorite Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. Shutter Speed will now compete in France's Oaks, while Gosden will decide whether to enter his colt Cracksman in the Derby trial. The trainer expressed satisfaction with Shutter Speed's performance and noted the soft ground as a factor. He will also prepare Shutter Speed for Chantilly, with stablemates Enable and Coronet as top contenders for the Oaks at Epsom. The gap between the Dante Stakes and the Derby is 16 days.

The British pound initially fell against the dollar and euro, but started recovering before falling again. The "volatility index" hit levels last seen during the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign argued that the pound had retreated to March levels, with the pound down 0.2% against the dollar and 0.6% against the euro. Investors were spooked by data showing the chances of a Remain vote had fallen, and two polls put the Leave camp ahead. The markets were rattled by global economic worries and the potential impact of Brexit on trade and the UK's economy. The FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group the biggest faller. Leave campaigner Nigel Farage argued that sterling had strengthened since March and that a weaker pound was good for UK exporters.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, just outside the play-off spots, after a tough match against Barrow, which extended Barrow's unbeaten run to nine games. Despite the loss, Cowley remains positive, calling the journey remarkable and expressing determination to embrace the challenge.

The passage discusses a controversial change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where elected politicians will make most planning decisions, previously handled by the Planning Service. This shift, starting from April 2015, aims to democratize the planning system, with local councils developing their own community and development plans. However, concerns arise about potential discrimination, favoritism, and the need for transparency, especially regarding political donations. Critics fear a return to past issues of discrimination and close relationships between developers and political parties, while some politicians worry about personal security and the relevance of the £7,500 donation limit.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The cat was found injured by her owner, Sarah Nisbett, in NiddryView, Winchburgh, and taken to the Scottish SPCA. The incident has raised concerns about the need for licensing air weapons, as the Scottish government had previously held a consultation on the matter, with a majority opposing the plan. The Scottish SPCA and the cat's owner are urging for the responsible person to be identified and for the implementation of the licensing scheme.

Liverpool has signed Belgian international Romelu Lukaku, who will be their second most expensive signing on a long-term contract. Lukaku, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, is joining the team to help revive their attack after struggling for goals last season. He will be joining other new signings like Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, Danny Ings, and Roberto Firmino. Lukaku, who missed the 2014 World Cup due to an injury, is expected to do well at Liverpool, with former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge expressing their excitement for his addition to the team.

The study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices, despite their widespread use in schools. The study, led by Barbie Clarke, examined 671 schools and found that tablets are now used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools. However, the study also found that many pupils use tablets for non-academic purposes, such as social media, and that the impact of tablets on academic performance cannot be definitively linked. Despite this, some head teachers reported a positive impact of tablets on student motivation and engagement, and a separate study suggested that touch-screen computers can help boys and poorer pupils learn to read. The study also found that tablets are becoming an integral part of students' lives, both in school and at home.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs depicting the lives of children in Liverpool from the 1880s to the 1990s, showcasing both joyful and challenging aspects of childhood, and is curated by Kay Jones.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has mutually agreed to leave Barrow to join National League rivals, potentially playing against them on 18 February. Striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, and his move is pending international clearance. Nicholson praised Keating's leadership qualities, while the Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

The new Bolivian law allows 12-year-olds to work with parental consent, reflecting the country's poverty and setting a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide. The law, signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera, aims to address extreme poverty and child labor, despite the International Labour Organisation's stance against child labor under 15.

A 50-year-old woman, after experiencing symptoms of a heart attack, searched online for "women's heart attack symptoms" and took aspirin before visiting a cardiologist who inserted a stent into a nearly blocked artery. She later shared her experience in a blog post, warning others to recognize symptoms and call 911, despite not having done so herself. She is a former host of The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network.

A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, from Harrow, was stabbed to death at a party in Kenton, Belvedere Way, after a fight with youths. He was pronounced dead an hour later. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, and two boys aged 15 and 16 were also arrested on suspicion of murder and bailed until mid-December. A 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon.

The passage describes Denmark's new approach to cancer diagnosis, which was developed in response to poor cancer survival rates. The model includes three routes: fast-track diagnosis for patients with specific cancer symptoms, diagnosis centres for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, and "yes-no" centres for patients with minor symptoms. The changes have led to better organization of patient diagnosis, improved survival rates, and have the potential to be shared with Wales.

The UK government has decided to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), and Powys will take over the role of issuing warning and banning orders against dishonest estate agents, receiving £170,000 annually for the service. Complaints about estate agents will still be directed to local authority trading standards departments, which will prosecute offenders if necessary. Powys will refer cases to them if they believe parts of the Estate Agents Act have been breached. James Munro from Powys council, who will lead the new team, hopes this will allow Powys to take on more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the NHS workforce, with the Nuffield Trust highlighting the potential for nurses and other health staff to take on more roles, such as covering for doctor shortages and managing long-term conditions. However, unions have warned against using this as a quick fix for NHS staffing issues, emphasizing the need for good quality training and adequate funding for training courses.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place outside the First depot due to a crash at 03:00 GMT, causing disruption and delays to commuters and bus services. The A36 road closure was lifted at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First's managing director, James Freeman, stated that while some services had resumed, it would take a few hours for all services to return to normal. He thanked the public and staff for their support and efforts in managing the situation.

NRW estimated that the Swansea tidal lagoon project would result in 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying annually, but TLP disputed these figures, claiming they lacked a clear scientific basis and accusing NRW of not sharing its methodology. TLP's own computer modelling suggested a worst-case scenario of 2% fish mortality. The UK government is reviewing the project's viability, and Wales' Environment Secretary expressed support but sought clarity on the government's position. NRW defended its figures, stating they were based on the best available evidence and had been thoroughly assessed by independent experts.

The Northern Ireland government announced the creation of a new agri-food marketing body, led by the Agri-Food Strategy Board, to improve coordination and strategic leadership in the agri-food sector, which is vital for the region's economy and employs nearly 100,000 people.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree-planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, inviting the public to plant 40,000 native UK trees to honor those who died in WW1, with the project aiming to create a living tribute to the Irish people who participated in the war.

Hilary won Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her book "Someone Else's Skin," which was praised for its emotional depth and strong writing. US author Sara Paretsky, creator of detective VI Warshawski, received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23-year career in crime fiction. The awards were presented at Harrogate's annual crime writing festival, where Ann Cleeves, the festival's programming chair, commended the strong shortlist and Hilary's finely written novel. Paretsky's work, including her creation of VI Warshawski, was noted for changing perceptions of female writers, and she founded Sisters In Crime to support female crime writers globally.

Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, broke his finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant setback for the team. The injury occurred in the first T20 game, and he expressed frustration at the timing. Santner, who made his Test debut in 2015, is set to rejoin the team after the ICC Trophy in England. In August, Worcestershire signed John Hastings, an Australian pace bowler, as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a millionaire, was killed by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008, with his wife, Ganna Ziuzina, implicated in the incident. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, ruled the death as unlawful, influenced by Ziuzina's inebriation and the car's stolen license plates. Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than Pring, tried to claim his assets and was suspected of staging the hit-and-run to inherit his money. Despite attempts to get her to attend the inquest, she made no further statements. The case remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns announced that her son Charlie, who requires experimental T-Cell Therapy in Seattle, USA, after unsuccessful treatment in the UK, will receive the necessary care. The treatment, funded by an anonymous donor, was confirmed via email, and Charlie's parents expressed their gratitude for the generosity. The therapy is set to begin as soon as possible, with the exact date to be determined next week.

The passage discusses the use of third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud. Apple has introduced a two-step verification process to prevent such breaches, which requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone or via Apple's Find My iPhone app. The process also includes a 14-character recovery key for account recovery. However, the security measure remains optional, and experts suggest making it the default option. Apple plans to encourage more users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords. The owner of Elcomsoft's software acknowledges that Apple's changes guard against his software's techniques.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of Wright's potential 20% club purchase are still forthcoming. Wright, 30, is set to become a club director, while Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, are three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, a former non-league player, has a history with clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. Billericay was recently acquired by billionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is willing to invest £10,000 weekly. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky in March.

Mr Ashley, owner of Derbyshire company and Newcastle United Football Club, was asked to give evidence about worker treatment following a BBC investigation. He was invited to a meeting with the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, chaired by Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, to discuss the treatment of low-paid workers and enforcement of the national minimum wage. Mr Ashley has until 21 March to respond to the invitation. The BIS committee has offered alternative dates for the meeting, but Mr Ashley has not accepted any. If he fails to agree to attend, the committee may seek the support of the House of Commons. Sports Direct, the company, has not yet responded to the BBC's request for a comment.

The report, "Putin. War," led by Ilya Yashin, accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, based on facts from Russian and foreign media since 2014. It claims Russian soldiers and equipment were decisive in victories claimed by pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine, contradicting Russia's denial of sending regular troops. The report, which includes evidence of volunteer soldiers and details of Russian spending on the conflict, was started by Boris Nemtsov and aims to expose the human and economic cost of the conflict. However, publishing and distribution challenges remain, and the report's impact is uncertain.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem revealed he died from head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister, expressed frustration over not being consulted on the Article 50 letter, which outlines the UK's plan to leave the EU, and criticized the UK government for not respecting the devolved administrations. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the UK government's actions, stating that the devolved administrations have made their representations. Mrs May's letter to Donald Tusk mentioned the return of powers to the UK, with the expectation of increased decision-making power for each devolved administration, but did not specify which powers. Concerns were raised about the potential lack of funding to accompany devolved powers after 2020, and the identity of the powers the UK government wants to see devolved remains unclear.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay at the attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page stated that police were performing their duties when attacked and appealed to parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, founder and former CEO of American Apparel, was ousted due to employee complaints and accusations of misuse of funds. He was accused of sending illicit emails and making racially derogatory comments to female employees, violating the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. His lawyer claimed many accusations were false and an invasion of privacy. The company's board stated they did not expect him to return, citing the risk to the company and its shareholders. A restraining order was granted to prevent Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company.

The passage discusses the upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The game, held in Patras, Greece, saw Greece win 92-64. Three Greek players will be absent, giving Great Britain a chance for revenge. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing in London, especially for those playing for the first time. This game is Great Britain's only home game before the FIBA EuroBasket 2017, starting in September, with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. After the Greece game, Great Britain's team will travel to a four-team tournament in Poland as their last warm-up before EuroBasket.

The passage describes the transformative impact of the iPhone, introduced by Steve Jobs, on technology and society. The author recalls an early encounter with the iPhone, which was not yet widely available, and reflects on its revolutionary role in changing how people use their phones, particularly in photography. The iPhone's user-friendly interface, compared to previous mobile devices, made it popular for more than just calls and texts. The author acknowledges the hyperbole around the iPhone's launch but appreciates witnessing a pivotal moment in history. The passage also mentions the ongoing advancements in technology by companies like Amazon and Google, with a nod to the iPhone's role in starting the mobile connected era.

The RSPCA confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue, Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, had ingested antifreeze, leading to the death of seven-month-old Meereen and three other cats in the area. The cause of the poisonings is unknown, and the RSPCA is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially during the antifreeze season.

The Syriza government in Greece, despite being expected to implement more austerity measures, sees a surge in tourist arrivals at Athens airport, with 25 million expected this year. However, Greeks are not protesting against the announced VAT increases, pension cuts, and other austerity measures, possibly due to the upcoming revelation of the concessions made by Alexis Tsipras to secure €86bn in new credit from the eurozone and the IMF. Despite failing to end fiscal austerity, Tsipras remains popular, and the new bailout may only succeed if it offers hope of better times ahead. Critics argue that creditors should ease Greece's debt burden to pave the way for genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will make a brief return to EastEnders to reunite the Mitchell family for the final time. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character, will say goodbye to his mother, Barbara, who has returned to Albert Square after a surprise comeback. Barbara's character will be killed off due to her cancer, which has returned. The reunion and the emotional scenes will be filmed and screened in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and then again in 2005 and 2006, is looking forward to filming these classic episodes. EastEnders executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins expressed excitement about the opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles, leading to his conviction and a minimum sentence of 22 years. Dhillon's obsession with Ruggles began two days before her death, during a phone call with her mother, who initially reassured her daughter but later felt guilty for not taking the situation more seriously. Ruggles' parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, hoping to honor their daughter's memory as a "smiling and laughing" individual.

The French firm EDF, financing the £18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, has received government approval, but Business Secretary Greg Clark has expressed the need for careful consideration. Critics worry about environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign involvement, with one-third of the cost funded by Chinese investors. The government is conducting a further review, and EDF's CEO canceled a trip following Clark's comments. The project, expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity, has faced financial concerns for EDF, leading to shareholder and executive resignations. Environmentalists and industry experts urge a swift decision to avoid energy supply issues and to meet climate commitments. The project's approval and investment agreements have been delayed multiple times, with the UK government agreeing to pay a higher rate for electricity produced at the site.

The updated divorce application form in England and Wales now asks for the name of the person a spouse has committed adultery with, which family lawyers say can add conflict and complexity. While there is no obligation to name the third party, doing so can involve them in the court case, potentially delaying proceedings and increasing costs. The form aims to be more user-friendly, but concerns remain about the potential for increased conflict and the negative perception of petitioners who name new partners.

The passage discusses the tension between environmental concerns and the timber industry in Wales. While the government encourages woodland creation and aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social factors, there is a push for more native tree species and access for recreation, which some believe conflicts with commercial forestry. The industry, worth over £450m annually, faces challenges in replanting lost forests and meeting long-term targets, with the current system seen as too bureaucratic. The Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy aim to enhance the landscape and support the industry, but there is a call for more action to meet the demand for timber.

A boy was seriously injured in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, and was taken to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. Emergency crews responded to the scene on Bank Street at approximately 4:40 PM.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoy veterans, despite initial Foreign Office objections, as a symbol of Russia's gratitude for their role in defeating the Germans on the Eastern Front during WWII. The Arctic Convoys were perilous missions that involved constant threats and harsh conditions, resulting in the loss of thousands of Allied seamen. The Russian Embassy's intention to award the medals was initially blocked by the Foreign Office's rules, but an exception was made, and President Putin presented the first medals in 2013. The Arctic Star was created by the British Government in 2012 to honor the veterans, but campaigners still supported the Russian accolade.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation report highlighted delays in offenders starting their work and leniency in cases of non-attendance, with one offender completing only 16 hours in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's 15 recommendations, which include reducing the number of offenders turned away from work, creating objectives for unpaid work that match the offender's circumstances, and ensuring offenders face consequences for non-attendance. The report also praised high-quality work and instances where offenders gained skills and viewed their sentence positively. The Ministry of Justice aims for more effective rehabilitation, starting with ensuring offenders turn up on time.

The comedian, known for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor, faces accusations of hypocrisy due to his luxurious lifestyle. Despite his wealth, he has expressed a desire for personal change and wealth sharing, while acknowledging the need for systemic change to address economic disparity and ecological disaster. He has been criticized for his past actions and fame, but defends himself by stating that the focus on inequality is necessary. He also criticizes the media for not addressing the real issues.

Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the mapping of the human genome, leading to the creation of Synthia, a synthetic life form, and founding Celera Genomics to expedite the decoding of the human genetic code. Despite criticism and controversy, Venter's work has significantly advanced genomics and opened possibilities for environmental benefits through synthetic biology.

A survey commissioned by England's School Food Trust found that 80% of children who eat school lunches in England try new foods at school that they haven't tried at home, and 50% of parents want their children to eat these foods at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. The research was conducted among 628 parents of children who eat school lunches, and it was found that school meals have become healthier and more varied, with 40% of primary school children in England now eating school lunches.

Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish player, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. His move included an option for Real to buy him back for up to 30m euros. Morata, who previously attracted interest from Arsenal and Chelsea, has scored three times for Spain in Euro 2016. At Juventus, he scored 27 goals in two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in back-to-back Champions League finals, debuting at 18 for Real Madrid and scoring 10 goals for them.

Wilson rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, but was released in May and has been without a team since. He made 51 appearances in his second spell at the City Ground, having previously played for Celtic, Preston North End, and Notts County.

The British supermarket giant, Tesco, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a private equity company. Around 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to Yucaipa, and Tesco will loan the new business around £80m. Fresh & Easy, which has been unprofitable since 2007, operates 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona. Tesco will close the remaining 50 stores, and the disposal of the Fresh & Easy brand will cost Tesco £150m, part of which is a loan. If Yucaipa's business becomes profitable, Tesco has the option to buy a stake. Yucaipa is run by billionaire investor Ron Burkle.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it, considering representing France before focusing on winning a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. It also mentions a guide on how to get into martial arts.

The ice fields on Mont Blanc and surrounding mountains in the European Alps have shrunk from 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to 275 sq km by the late 2000s, as presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting. The new French Alps glaciers inventory, produced by Marie Gardent and colleagues, assessed roughly 600 glaciers across several massifs, using map archives, satellite imagery, and manual inspection. The retreat is not uniform, with the greatest losses in the southern sectors, and the northern Alps experiencing less retreat due to lower elevation and different climatic conditions. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has reduced from 31.5 sq km to just over 30 sq km. Efforts to monitor glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region.

Scotland, who have won all five qualifiers, are set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with victory likely securing their place in the finals. Despite past play-off losses, Scotland's goalkeeper Gemma Fay and forward Evans are determined to reach the finals, aiming to avoid the heartbreak of missing out. With Iceland ranked 20th in the world and unbeaten, the outcome of the match and the return fixture will determine the group leader. Scotland, in pole position, could reach the finals without a play-off, with the best six runners-up also qualifying. Evans, a key player, has benefited from playing in top leagues, which she believes enhances the national team.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and former computer games reviewer, was arrested in the west of England after a woman in south London filed a complaint of harassment over two years, allegedly related to his tweets. Campbell, who has been a proponent of Scottish independence, was released on bail and accused the media of using innuendo to fuel speculation. He insisted his tweets were not threatening and has been asked to appear in court in mid-September.

Peta, an animal rights group, has proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot in Skegness with a fish featuring the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice" to promote a more animal-friendly image. The original mascot, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908, has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. Peta argues that the Jolly Fisherman represents animal cruelty, while Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, believes the mascot is beloved and should remain unchanged. The council will decide on the proposal.

Scotland dominated the rugby match, scoring five tries and maintaining 91% possession, while Georgia managed to score two tries, resulting in a final score of 38-11 in favor of Scotland. Key players for Scotland included Stuart Hogg, Sean Maitland, and Greig Laidlaw, while Georgia's notable players were Merab Kvirikashvili and Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland's coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance and noted improvements in their approach to the game.

Widnes secured a 38-12 victory over Castleford, with key contributions from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, and Cas loanee Paddy Flynn. Despite Castleford's three tries in four minutes, including a hat-trick from Flynn, Widnes held on. Castleford's Solomona, Monaghan, Crooks, Webster, Flynn, McShane, Gale, Jewitt, Milner, Patrick, Moors, McMeeken, and Massey played, with replacements Millington, Springer, Tickle, and Cook. Widnes' lineup included Hanbury, Thompson, Runciman, Bridge, Ah Van, Mellor, Brown, Cahill, White, Buchanan, Whitley, Dean, and Leuluai, with J. Chapelhow, Manuokafoa, Walker, and Heremaia as replacements. The match was refereed by J Smith.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old man detained in Guantanamo Bay since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, was released by the US after a review panel found he was not a continuing significant threat. He boarded a Kuwaiti government plane, expressing joy and no bitterness. He will spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His release brings the total number of inmates at the US naval base to 148, and he is the first inmate to be freed since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl.

Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 people participating in a parade before a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph for Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One. The service also took place at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. The event, attended by thousands of expatriate and visiting New Zealanders and Australians, included a speech by Alexander Downer, Australian high commissioner to the UK, and a parade featuring veterans' associations, service and ex-service personnel, and their families. The ceremony also featured prayers read by schoolchildren and the national anthems of all three countries. Anzac Day commemorates the eight-month Gallipoli campaign, one of the bloodiest of the war, aimed at forcing the Ottoman empire out of the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old footballer, has joined Premiership Well for a second spell and is set to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa. He scored nine goals at Dundee last season and has mostly played as a substitute this term. He has been training hard to stay match fit and is looking forward to his debut. Clarkson has made almost 400 senior appearances at club level and has been capped twice for Scotland in 2008. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points clear of Alloa.

The turkey firm was sold to Ranjit Boparan, who assured existing workers that their pension scheme would be honored. The Boparan Private Office confirmed that current pension arrangements with Bernard Matthews would continue under new ownership. Boparan aims to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken, not just turkeys.

A council scrutiny meeting discussed issues with a new ferry, including breakdowns, groundings, and training problems, leading to free crossings until 2 July and a review by auditors. Local businesses, like Angie Booth's shop, are suffering from the loss of trade, and compensation for damages is being considered. Transport councillor Ian Ward views the problems as teething issues of a prototype ferry, with some resolved, such as electrical problems and groundings due to seamanship.

The Lords review warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a Brexit deal, potentially marginalizing fishing communities. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been a point of contention, with the UK industry seeking to regain control over UK waters post-Brexit. The report highlights the need for continued market access and the retention of CFP elements, but also raises concerns about different fisheries management regimes in the UK. Despite these concerns, the fishing industry remains optimistic about the opportunities Brexit may bring, especially with the EU's new quotas under the CFP. The UK government emphasizes the desire for maximum trade freedom while reviewing fisheries management.

Timothy Geaney, a 69-year-old former teacher, admitted to downloading images of young boys in erotic poses from April 2004 to February 2014. He was made the subject of a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special program for sex offenders. Geaney was removed from his profession's register by General Teaching Council Scotland due to his conduct, which was deemed incompatible with being a registered teacher. He was prohibited from re-registering for two years.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street after a blaze on 2 March, which led to travel delays and reduced train services. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, run by Asset and Land Group, from accepting waste due to fire safety concerns. The company, which had been broadly compliant with fire safety laws, was unable to comment and has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective after 7 August, following a series of joint visits by fire safety officers and EA staff. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, despite missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. He mentioned that two shipments of weapons were intercepted by terrorist groups. Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements in Syria. The Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported that rebels had taken control of the prison. Russia, a key ally of Syria, urged Damascus to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons by 1 March. The OPCW has admitted that the destruction process has been slowed by security concerns.

England won the cricket series against Pakistan with a significant lead, thanks to Joe Root's outstanding performance, which included a 254-run first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. The victory was achieved with a day to spare at Old Trafford, marking England's second-largest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. The series is described as very tight, with England expected to win again, while Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment and a need for mental strength and improved shot selection.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, will gather experiences from pensioners and their families in residential care to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. This is part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. Rochira will also review factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. However, the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that a provider expert is not included on the main advisory panel.

Former Dons midfielder Sheerin, 39, has been player-manager at the Red Lichties since 2010, replacing Neil Cooper at Pittodrie. Aberdeen's chief executive Duncan Fraser stated that Sheerin was chosen by boss Derek McInnes after a comprehensive process. Despite wishing to retain Sheerin, Arbroath chairman John Christison was agreeable to his return to Aberdeen. Sheerin, who played for several Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, won a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. He led Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's match against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's dismissal. The club, which was promoted to the Premier League in 2011, is looking to appoint a new manager soon, with Paul Clement as the preferred choice. Former player Curtis believes the team has lost its way since Michael Laudrup left in 2014, and the current squad is capable of staying in the Premier League.

Dr. J Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, revolutionized the mapping of the human genome, leading to the creation of Synthia, a synthetic life form, and sparked controversy for his methods and commercial ventures, while also pursuing oceanic genetic research.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short, with only 20% rated at level three, compared to over 50% in Germany. The report calls for the creation of up to 300,000 new apprenticeships each year, with a focus on level three and four courses, and a reduction in two-year level two courses. The Department for Education is reforming apprenticeships to improve standards, while the Association of Colleges supports the preservation of some existing level two apprenticeships. The report highlights the need for high-quality vocational education and better career guidance.

The Briton, Storey, won the cycling race in Nottwil, Switzerland, more than two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska, with a chance to win a 17th title in the upcoming road race. Storey, a 37-year-old Paralympian, has 22 medals, including 11 golds, and is aiming for further success at the Rio de Janeiro Games. She began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005. Storey has also won 21 world titles in both sports.

Hereford United faced financial difficulties, with debts totaling £148,000, and failed to meet a payment deadline, leading to their expulsion from the Conference Premier. The club was taken over by Tommy Agombar, and Chester City replaced them in the league. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust offered to buy the club for £1 to clear debts, but Agombar's takeover proceeded. The club's financial woes were worsened by falling attendance, with an average of 1,758 fans per game in the 2013-14 season, compared to 3,270 in League Two five years prior.

The former Manchester City player, 30, has won 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009, including participation in two World Cups and two European Championships, with a brief appearance at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, having scored his only international goal in a 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers match.

Christopher Hogwood, a prominent figure in the early-music movement, passed away after a prolonged illness. He was a founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for 30 years and produced over 200 CDs, including a complete cycle of Mozart symphonies. Hogwood was also a keyboard player, musicologist, and tutor at Harvard University, among other roles. He was remembered for his generosity, academic prowess, and his significant influence on the development of historically informed music. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected by his family, is struggling in mainstream school and has been placed in a special school. His family is concerned about the lack of capacity in special schools, and the Education Authority is reviewing the need for special school places to better serve children in the future.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is planning a takeover bid for Newport Gwent Dragons, a football club with a 10-year lease on Rodney Parade stadium, which they see as a rugby venue. The club's current lease and fixture primacy are protected, and the takeover will be voted on by shareholders on May 9. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules, and Newport Gwent Dragons are currently two points clear of relegation. The club's chairman, Will Godfrey, has stated that both the club and the Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements.

The passage describes the experiences of an individual who was kidnapped by the RUF rebels during the Sierra Leone civil war, trained in violence, and later escaped to Freetown. He was imprisoned but met a preacher, Richard Cole, who inspired him to contribute positively to rebuilding the nation. During the 2014 Ebola crisis, he and others developed a clinic to educate and support communities, saving many lives. The individual reflects on his past actions, regrets them, and now believes in investing in young people to build a better future. The passage also provides statistics on Ebola-related deaths in various countries.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised enough money to prevent the auction of 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs, which were at risk due to the pottery firm's pension debt. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The successful campaign was led by The Art Fund, and the sale was described as "incredibly satisfying" by administrators. The collection, which is significant for Staffordshire and British cultural history, was at risk of being sold and scattered globally.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of Wright's potential 20% club ownership are still forthcoming. Wright, 30, will be a club director, and Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, are three points behind a play-off spot. Wright, who previously played non-league football for clubs like Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds, was runner-up in "I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here" in 2011. Billericay was recently acquired by billionaire Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 weekly. The club also signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in March.

Blackpool and Colchester United ended their match 1-1 after 17 minutes, with Blackpool equalizing from a corner and Colchester United also equalizing from a corner. Blackpool's Sam Slocombe made a crucial save, and Colchester United had to play with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a chance to score, and the match saw several free kicks, fouls, and substitutions. Both teams had players sent off, with Slocombe and Murray receiving red cards. The match was tightly contested, with both teams having opportunities to take the lead.

The Fawley Waterside developers plan to transform the disused Fawley power station chimney into the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, as part of a £1bn "merchant city" development. The project, which will include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, is set to start building in 2018. The power station, which closed in 2013 after 40 years of operation, was commissioned in 1971 and could power one million homes. The developers see the project as a cost-effective way to create a spectacular attraction.

23-year-old Latham won GB's second medal at the Hong Kong championships, taking bronze in the men's team pursuit after chasing down gold medalist Adrian Teklinski. Despite a strong performance, GB finished fifth in the women's team pursuit. Chris Boardman praised Latham's final sprint, while Elinor Barker, Olympic gold medallist, commended the young squad's progress. Katy Marchant, Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated in the women's sprint, expressing disappointment but remaining optimistic about her future competitions.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, will return to EastEnders for Barbara Mitchell's final episodes. Barbara, played by Dame Barbara, will be killed off after reappearing to tell her son Phil (Steve McFadden) that her cancer has returned. The storyline will reunite Grant Mitchell with his mother and brother, Phil, for the last time. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character since 1990, will say goodbye to his mother in emotional scenes. The Mitchell brothers will face the loss of their mother, showcasing Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best. The episodes are set to be classic EastEnders episodes.

Sadio Mane scored twice in 138 seconds as Spurs lost to second-placed Chelsea at Anfield, disappointing Spurs' manager Mauricio Pochettino. Pochettino expressed concern over Spurs' lack of desire to win, which could hinder their Premier League aspirations. Spurs' recent road performance has been poor, with only two wins since 24 September, including losses to Chelsea and Manchester United, and draws against Arsenal and Manchester City. Pochettino emphasized the need for Spurs to cope with pressure to remain competitive in the Premier League. Former Liverpool and Spurs midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' inconsistent defensive record and suggested they should stick to their successful strategy against big sides. Murphy also noted the stark contrast in Spurs' performance at home versus away, highlighting a lack of pace and a different mindset when playing away from home.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of the 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State. The APC made significant gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party, but failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP will need to undergo introspection and rebuild under a new leader after 16 years in power and facing allegations of corruption and failure to address the north-east insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will feature acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. Visitors can use an app to access online information from signs and posters, view videos and band interviews, and interact with the festival from anywhere. The app will also provide updates, ticket purchases, and a taste of the festival's unique atmosphere.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, with Park View and Oldknow Academy also at risk of losing funding. A head teacher at one of the Trojan Horse schools reported parents undermining her authority during an Ofsted inspection. The Department for Education, led by Lord Nash, expressed "deep concerns" about Park View's management and demanded changes, including ending segregation and ensuring a broad curriculum. Park View and Oldknow Trusts plan to challenge the Ofsted reports legally. The report criticized Park View for inadequate safety measures and improper vetting of external speakers. Parents and staff at the schools have criticized Ofsted's findings and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, also known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich, where eye specialist Honey Rose failed to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution alleges that Rose's negligence, which fell far below the expected standard of a competent optometrist, led to Vinnie's death, which was preventable. Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter, and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity with a man he met on an adult website, and of sending a sexually explicit clip to her sister on Christmas Day. He was also convicted of causing her sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening manner. Weatherhogg, who had previously denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register and remanded in custody ahead of sentencing. The judge described him as a first offender posing a moderate risk of re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in a T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson, Gary Wilson, and William Porterfield contributing significantly. However, Afghanistan won with a score of 171-4, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari, Mohammad Shahzad, and Najeeb Tarakai. The Irish team faced challenges, including the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin and an early dismissal of Paul Stirling. The teams are set to meet again in a second T20 match. Porterfield noted that they fell short of their target by 15 runs and felt they could have executed better with the ball. Rankin is expected to return for the five ODIs against Afghanistan.

FC Barcelona paid £48.6m for Neymar, but allegations suggest the actual cost, including fees and taxes, was £106.8m. Sandro Rosell, the former president, is under investigation for misappropriation of funds. A Spanish judge ruled there was enough evidence to continue the investigation, but the club has made a tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros, claiming the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge, both 23 and 24, were found dead on a beach in Koh Tao on 15 September. UK police, in collaboration with Thai authorities, are compiling a report on the case. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are charged with their murders, conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty. The UK Foreign Office had previously expressed concerns about the Thai police investigation, particularly regarding DNA sample verification and alleged mistreatment of suspects. Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha agreed to a UK police visit after meeting with UK Prime Minister Cameron. Post-mortem examinations revealed drowning and a blow to the head for Miller, and head wounds for Witheridge. Thai police claim DNA from the victims matches samples from the suspects.

Scotland, with a strong track record in qualifiers, is set to host Iceland in the World Cup qualifiers, aiming to secure their place in the finals. The Scottish team, led by 24-year-old forward Evans, is determined to avoid another play-off loss, having experienced such setbacks in the past. Evans, who has played for various clubs, including Bayern Munich, believes that the experience of playing in top leagues like Germany's women's Bundesliga benefits the national team. The Scottish Women's Premier League is also improving, with players gaining new perspectives from playing abroad. The outcome of the upcoming match and the return fixture in Reykjavik will likely determine the group leader.

The passage discusses the recent use of third-party software to steal celebrities' intimate photos from iCloud, leading Apple to implement a two-step verification process to prevent such breaches. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code after entering their username and password, and if the code is not entered, access to iCloud is denied. Apple had previously offered this two-step verification but it was not used with iCloud backups. The owner of ElcomSoft, a software used by hackers, acknowledged that his software could not bypass the new security measures. However, concerns remain about the recovery key, which could be lost or stolen, potentially leading to data loss. Experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default option for better security. Apple plans to encourage users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords.

UKIP, the Tories, the Lib Dems, Labour, and the Green Party spent varying amounts on their campaigns, with UKIP spending £2,956,737 and Labour £1,027,339. The figures cover the campaign period from 23 January to polling day, 22 May. UKIP's campaign spending works out at 68p for each of their 4,376,635 votes, Labour's at 26p, the Conservatives' at 79p, and the Lib Dems' at £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249 on its campaign, which works out at 43p for each of its 1,255,573 votes. The six highest-spending parties spent a total of £9,347,087 on campaigning. All but Labour spent more than they did during the 2009 European election campaign.

Anderson, a 27-year-old centre-back, has mutually agreed to leave Barrow to join National League rivals, while striker Keating, 21, has been recommended to Gulls by Micky Adams and is awaiting international clearance.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse suffered from a rare "severe pulmonary haemorrhage" and had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but had never collapsed before. The British Horseracing Authority and veterinary officials are investigating the cause of the haemorrhage.

Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, and veteran MSP Duncan McNeil bid farewell to the parliament, with McNeil warning Holyrood to learn from Westminster. Former first minister Alex Salmond also addressed the chamber, reiterating his belief in Scotland's diversity and calling for greater responsibility for Scotland's governance. Salmond also expressed his views on the Scotland Bill and the upcoming election. Annabel Goldie, another departing MSP, joked about her time with Finance Secretary John Swinney. All three politicians, Salmond, McNeil, and Goldie, are standing down ahead of the election on May 5.

Emma Watson, Kevin Kline, Dan Stevens, and Luke Evans are cast in the upcoming live-action adaptation of Beauty and the Beast, with Bill Condon directing and filming set to begin at Shepperton Studios in May. The film will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans died, at a meeting with victims' relatives. New inquests last year concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. In January, evidence related to 23 suspects was referred to the CPS to decide on charges. The decisions will be made by Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter-terrorism division at the CPS.
