Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, expressed hope for accountability and stated that the families are determined to never give up.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced "numerous incidents" of packages being thrown over the wall, with former inmates describing the facility as "notorious" for flooding with contraband like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the issue and is working hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons, with the Justice Secretary seeking ways to better equip prisons to handle such problems. A local resident has reported witnessing packages being thrown over the wall multiple times in a short period, and while the Ministry denies evidence of drones being used, they have introduced laws that could jail individuals smuggling packages for up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, a 55-year-old man, while crossing the road outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright, who was blinded by the setting sun, admitted to striking Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He failed to stop for a red light, and the court heard that the sun could have been shining into his eyes, causing him to be blinded. The trial continues.

Hellen Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will not be with the Scotland team at the Commonwealth Games in April due to her veterinary medicine studies. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, setting a new outdoor personal best. Muir, who has expressed interest in the World Indoor Championships in March, is currently focused on completing her final year of university. Despite missing the Commonwealth Games, she remains optimistic about her future in athletics, with potential for more Olympic participation.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man, went missing after a Christmas party in December 2000. A search for him began in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations and expected to take weeks. A review of his disappearance was initiated earlier this year, and CCTV footage from the night he disappeared shows him talking to a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland. The man, who Deely was returning to get an umbrella, was later seen on Haddington Road, but has not yet been identified.

Del Potro, ranked 165th, won a thrilling match against Swiss player Wawrinka, 31, in the Wimbledon quarterfinals, marking his return to Grand Slam play after three wrist surgeries. Del Potro, who is in the same half of the draw as Britain's Andy Murray, will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios, also in the same half of the draw as Murray, advanced to the last 16 after a rain-affected match against Dustin Brown. Feliciano Lopez will face Kyrgios in the third round, with the winner facing either Murray or John Millman. Other notable victories included Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga advancing to the next round.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against CAF, but after apologising, they were allowed to participate. Morocco, initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup, had their ban overturned by CAS, and a fine reduced. Equatorial Guinea hosted the 2015 finals, and Tunisia's row with CAF was resolved, allowing them to compete in the 2017 Nations Cup. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 finals would mark their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

The McLaren Formula 1 team, once a dominant force with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline after a successful history, including a partnership with Honda that led to multiple championships. Despite a resurgence in the current season, the team faces challenges with the Honda power unit. The team, led by Ron Dennis, is striving to regain its former glory and break Mercedes' hegemony in F1, with Fernando Alonso as a key driver. However, the team's past scandals and a history of fluctuating success cast doubt on their future prospects.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, Limavady, at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people at the bar, and till receipts showed alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, while James Thomas faced one count. The defense argued that Dungiven's licensing laws were not strictly followed. The judge criticized O'Neill's record and imposed fines: £3,000 on her and £1,000 on Thomas.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season with 45 points, helping the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry entered the game four shots shy of his previous record of 272 three-pointers, hitting eight in the game. Klay Thompson also contributed significantly with 26 points. The Warriors avoided their first three-game losing streak of the season. Meanwhile, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat 89-78, with Pau Gasol and Derrick Rose leading the scoring. The Heat struggled after halftime, missing their first 12 shots.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen, who they thought was a competition winner, arrived at Melwood. Van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, impressed the players by showcasing his abilities, including a perfect free-kick into the top corner. Van Velzen enjoyed the experience, especially meeting Balotelli and pretending to be a poor free-kick player. He also revealed Balotelli's famous slogan during a Manchester City game.

A study suggests that women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by 60% and 73% if they have their ovaries removed, with a 62% reduction in breast cancer death and a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The study analyzed 676 patients, finding a 77.4% 20-year survival rate for the group, and noted the protective effect of oophorectomy lasted for 15 years. The procedure is particularly effective for women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. The results suggest that oophorectomy should be considered in treatment discussions for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancers.

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were killed when an Amtrak train hit them on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina. The couple, aged 38 and 33, were on the tracks when the train, traveling from Charlotte to New York City, struck them. No other passengers were injured, although one man fell ill during the delay and received treatment. The couple may have been living in a homeless camp, as suggested by a man who collected scrap metal from them. The train was delayed for almost three hours before continuing its journey.

Carlos Toro, a former DEA informant who worked undercover for 27 years, is facing deportation after retiring. Toro, who was a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel in the 1980s, fled Colombia and later worked for the DEA, providing information on his former bosses and associates. He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work, but this has not been granted, leaving him living in the U.S. illegally. Toro's fears of being sent back to Colombia are justified, as his work helped in the prosecution of drug overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his contributions, the DEA has refused to help him with his citizenship, and he remains in a state of limbo, unable to collect social security benefits or secure a green card or passport. Toro is prepared to go into hiding if deported.

The U.S. body regulating internet addresses is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for using the'sucks' domain name to extort money from celebrities and companies. The domains, including those of celebrities like Kevin Spacey and major brands, have been sold for around $2,499 a year. The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is examining whether Vox Populi's actions are illegal, and if so, it could seek remedies or change the company's behavior. The advisory body has called the'sucks' domain a "shakedown scheme" and "predatory." Kevin Spacey is among those who have reportedly paid to have their domain names removed.

A mother of a baby boy, who was stillborn and found wrapped in a blanket in a Sainsbury's bag on a pond in Norfolk in 1988, was arrested 27 years later after DNA evidence led police to her. The charge of infanticide was dropped after she explained the circumstances, and the baby was reburied with a new headstone. The case, which had remained unsolved for decades, was closed with the help of modern DNA techniques.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to passenger Kristopher Hicks after leaving him with severe brain injuries by driving him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. Young, a former soldier, mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner." Hicks, who was 27, suffered devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The High Court ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact compensation amount is yet to be decided, but it is expected to be around 50% of the family's request, which they estimated to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds. The judge noted that Hicks' decision to jump out of the moving taxi at a dangerous speed led to his injuries. Both sides were given permission to appeal, and a further hearing will determine the final compensation amount.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night as several storms reported twisters, with one tornado about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, less than 15 miles west of Wichita, moving northeast and posing potential risks to other communities. CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers warned that nighttime tornadoes are the most deadly and dangerous. Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas near Aetna, 125 miles southwest of Wichita. The National Weather Service indicated a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, about 70 miles from St. Louis, with reports of wind damage and flooding. Aerial footage showed damage to roofs and a street overtaken by water. In the Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes, more storms are expected on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey, with Rockhold aiming to continue his winning streak and secure a title shot. Rockhold, who has been on a winning run since his loss to Vitor Belfort, believes he can dominate Machida by cutting him off and taking advantage of his weaknesses. Machida, confident in his ability to upset Rockhold, is also eyeing a title shot. Both fighters have expressed mutual respect for each other's skills and styles, with Rockhold emphasizing his readiness to dominate and Machida focusing on his strategy to win.

A light general aviation aircraft landed without its landing gear deployed at Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding and causing damage. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, managed to regain control and fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale, landing safely with his dog, Buddy, despite damaged propellers. The FAA is investigating the incident, which is attributed to human error, the most common cause of gear-up landings.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Ivory Coast midfielder Yaya Toure's performance but has committed to supporting him until the end of the season. The club is considering offers for Toure as they aim to revamp their aging squad. Toure, who has two years left on his contract, has been criticized for his underperformance, but Pellegrini insists he is a crucial player. The team will face West Ham without their captain Vincent Kompany due to a muscle injury. Meanwhile, West Ham manager Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell against making the same mistake as other English players who have moved to Manchester City, as Cresswell is a potential target for the club.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the godfather of Uxbridge, was set to be extradited to Italy but will remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in the UK for over 20 years, was convicted in absentia by an Italian court in 1999 for being a member of the Cosa Nostra. His conviction remains intact, but Italian law states that a sentence is extinguished once a period of more than double the time of the penalty has passed. The case will still need to be heard by the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore's solicitor, Karen Todner, expressed relief that the Italian government will withdraw their application for a European arrest warrant, allowing him to live peacefully in the UK with his family. The case has been criticized for the amount of time and money spent on it. Rancadore, who was first arrested in 2013, has lived under the name Marc Skinner for two decades. His father, Giuseppe, was imprisoned in 1987 as part of the Maxi Trial. Rancadore's case expired in October 2014, and the European arrest warrant is to be withdrawn.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in the seven-runner line-up for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, ridden by Aidan McCoy. The race features rivals including Irish Raider Special Tiara and Sacre, ridden by Nico de Boiville. Mr Mole will be McCoy's last ride in a Grade One race, with his final book of rides not yet finalized. Other runners include Mick Channon's Somersby. Ironically, McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to victory at Newbury in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, the mother of Marcia, who was murdered 40 years ago, has seen the crime scene photos of her daughter's body for the first time. Marcia, who was raped and strangled to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, had her body found 150 yards from her home. Barrett, who was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years, was arrested in 2006 after his DNA matched the clothing of the murdered child. Ritter, who had declined to see the photos for several decades, now wants revenge.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters at Augusta National to complete the career Grand Slam, joining an elite group of players who have achieved this feat. McIlroy, who has one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, views the Masters as a course where he can excel and hopes to win multiple times. Despite a career-defining collapse at Augusta in 2011, he has bounced back to win major titles, including the US Open, US PGA, and both the Open and US PGA in 2012. McIlroy sees the Masters as a sanctuary from the pressures of his career, including a recent legal dispute and the end of his marriage to Caroline Wozniacki. He aims to use the golf course to focus and perform at his best, hoping to add another green jacket to his collection.

A busy week of trending stories included rainbows in New York, exotic dancers in China, lip plumping inspired by Kylie Jenner, Alice Barker's time travel, a controversial prom-posal, Ewan McGregor playing Lumiere, Johnny Depp in 'Black Mass', pregnancy announcements referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombing his son.

New figures reveal that 272 children in England were hospitalized last year due to foetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by alcohol exposure in the womb. Experts warn the actual number affected could be higher, with WHO research suggesting at least 1 in 100 UK babies could suffer from related issues. The condition, which includes learning, behavioural, and physical problems, is lifelong and under-diagnosed. A teenager, Niamh Brown, exemplifies the impact, requiring assistance with daily tasks. The government advises pregnant women to limit alcohol consumption, but advocates like Elizabeth Mitchell suggest a total abstinence during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a former juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy," was jailed for six years after attempting to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham. He was foiled when the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled him, causing him to drop an axe. Dhillon's wife, Sam, helped by hitting McKerry with a baseball bat, disarming him. McKerry, who had a history of criminal behavior, was arrested by the police minutes later. He had previously pleaded guilty to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court. McKerry earned his nickname in the 1990s for always returning home after committing crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors charged with gang rape at a Canadian barracks party in Nova Scotia are to stay in the province until trial. They face unusual bail conditions, including living on a naval base, surrendering passports, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy. The accused, who were part of the Royal Navy ice hockey team, must not leave Nova Scotia, contact the victim or witnesses, or apply for new passports. The case is still in the early stages, with potential additional charges pending forensic test results. The Royal Navy will decide on their employment during the trial.

A mother, Valerie Jackson, whose son, Rj Jackson, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin disease causing red, inflamed, and scaly skin, was wrongly accused of child abuse by police after a member of the public reported her. The police surrounded her while she was shopping, mistaking her son's condition for signs of abuse. Despite the challenges, including taunts and bullying, Valerie continues to care for her son, who requires regular application of creams to manage his symptoms. She found support through an online group for families affected by Netherton's syndrome. Valerie hopes that as Rj grows, his condition will be better understood and accepted.

Transport for London (TFL) has removed controversial bikini-clad Protein World posters featuring model Renee Somerfield from the London Underground, following backlash from feminists and body image campaigners. The adverts, which have been defaced and criticized for promoting an unhealthy body image, were part of a three-week advertising period. TFL stated it would consider similar future adverts based on the Advertising Standards Authority's guidelines. The removal comes amid protests and social media outrage, with Protein World defending the campaign as promoting fitness and health. The company also reported receiving threats, including a bomb threat, and is under investigation. Sales of Protein World's products are rising in the UK.

Rail firms, including First Great Western, are facing criticism for planning fare hikes of up to 87% just ten days after the general election, despite promises from party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested an urgent review of First Great Western's decision to increase fares on the London to the Cotswolds route, which passes through his Witney constituency. Passengers traveling from Charlbury, Oxfordshire, will see their off-peak return fares from £33.30 to £62.40, a significant increase. Other rail companies, such as Virgin, are also introducing fare hikes, with Virgin's overall fare increase for the year being just 1.65%, well below the industry average. Both major political parties have pledged to freeze fares, but passengers are facing unexpected increases.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, were blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through their front door in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The couple, who had recently married, were writing thank you notes for wedding gifts when the attack occurred. John, a former Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineer, was hit in the left eye and suffered a serious injury to his forehead. Despite emergency surgery, doctors were unable to save his eyesight. The police launched an investigation but found no motive, suggesting the attack might have been a case of vandalism. The couple, who have no children, are now moving to Southport and feel too scared to return to their neighborhood. The police are urging anyone with information to come forward.

Tom Poynton, the 25-year-old Derbyshire wicketkeeper, has signed a one-year contract extension after a successful return from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that also claimed his father's life. Poynton, who missed the entire 2014 season, made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's exceptional character and hard work, expressing hope that the new contract will boost his confidence and performance for the upcoming season. Poynton is set to be available for the start of the season and will commit to Derbyshire until the end of the 2016 season.

A five-year-old boy, Harley Renshaw, who battled cancer in his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, was given the all-clear by doctors after creating a superhero mask to help him through his treatment. Harley, who was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, a kidney tumor removal operation, and a stem cell transplant. Despite complications, he returned home for his fifth birthday and was later declared cancer-free. Harley's bravery caught the attention of doctors, earning him a cancer research UK Little Star Award, and he became the face of the charity's kids and teens campaign. Harley's family is overjoyed and hopeful for his future. Neuroblastoma is a cancer of specialized nerve cells, affecting fewer than 100 children in the UK each year, and is the second most common solid tumor in childhood.

Tim Sherwood, Aston Villa's manager, advises Jack Grealish to focus on his club career rather than his international future, as he is currently in a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood emphasizes that Grealish must make his own decision, similar to Nabil Bentaleb's choice between France and Algeria. Grealish's father, Kevin, also supports prioritizing club football. Sherwood believes that Grealish's confidence and performance at Aston Villa will help him make the right choice, and he will have the opportunity to play for both Ireland and England in a friendly match.

Private jet landing fees vary significantly, with some airports charging thousands of pounds per landing. The most expensive airports are in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo charging £4,559, Narita International Airport at £3,728, and Kansai International Airport in Osaka at £3,594. Other notable fees include £2,929 at Bristol Airport in the UK, £2,630 at LaGuardia Airport in New York, and £2,530 at Salzburg Airport in Austria. The private jet industry is a lucrative market for the wealthy, with significant demand during major sporting events.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, took her labrador, Cooper, to a McDonald's drive-thru for an ice cream treat with his friend Daisy. Cooper, who eats very quickly, devoured the entire cone in one bite, while Daisy only managed a few licks. The video of Cooper's fast food indulgence has been viewed over seven million times. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, defends Cooper's eating habits, noting his athleticism and health. Cooper and Daisy also enjoy a Starbucks "pup-uccino," where Cooper again consumes the entire cup.

Gary Locke, the interim manager of Kilmarnock, has been appointed permanently after signing a three-year deal. He joined the club as an assistant manager to Allan Johnston last summer and took over when Johnston left in February. Locke has lost only one game in seven matches since assuming the role. He will address the press on Friday morning, and he shook hands with Chairman Jim Mann after signing the deal.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary School of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing essential oils manufactured by Doterra. The school claimed the oils were a distraction and caused a problem for staff and students. Despite the threat, the Lake County School District decided not to suspend Logan, considering it a health issue. Jessica Kemp insists the oils have a positive impact on her son and will continue to fight the school's decision. The family uses oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in the Hamptons, known as the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze, which started in one of the 90 condos, spread rapidly, causing intense smoke that could be seen from three miles away. Firefighters, despite their best efforts, were unable to enter the building due to the strength of the flames. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with claims it started near a car parked by the complex. The Sandpiper complex, used as a holiday home by residents between May and November, was completely ravaged by the fire.

The Queen, at 88, continues to enjoy riding her black fell pony, Carlton Lima Emma, in Windsor Great Park, despite a knee injury that has reduced her riding time. Known for her love of horses, she has ridden since age four and breeds several horse and pony breeds, including fell ponies, at her Hampton Court stud. The Queen has never worn a riding helmet, preferring a silk scarf, due to her hair. Fell ponies, which she breeds, have a rich history dating back to the Neolithic period and were used for various purposes, including trade and transportation, before becoming popular riding horses in the 1950s.

A 55-year-old man, Leon Yeaman, was killed by a single punch in the head from his 28-year-old neighbor, Phillip Pama, during a noise dispute in North Brisbane. Pama, a shift worker, was charged with manslaughter after the incident, which occurred around 9 pm on a Thursday night. Yeaman was making a lot of noise in his yard, and Pama, who was sleeping at the time, confronted him, leading to the fatal altercation. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene, and Pama was granted conditional bail, with restrictions including a curfew and mandatory police check-ins. The case is set to return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, was arrested after she attempted to hire a hitman to murder her 15-year-old ex-student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova, who had showered Vanya with gifts and money for a year, asked a friend to find someone to torture and kill him in exchange for 100,000 rubles (£1,400). An undercover police officer, posing as a hitman, recorded the conversation and Simonova's instructions. She was arrested in her car after handing over some expenses money. Simonova now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship with Simonova for another classmate, expressed relief at her arrest.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, revealed that he prays daily but never discusses football with his wife or God. He believes in separating his professional and family life and only prays for personal matters. Despite his competitive nature in football, he considers himself a good person and family man, and he supports people he doesn't even know. Mourinho was fined £25,000 earlier in the season for claiming there was a 'campaign' against Chelsea. He also mentioned that he and his family are aware of poverty and have worked with a food program as ambassadors against hunger.

For the first time in eight years, TV legend Bob Barker returned to hosting "The Price is Right," a role he held for 35 years before stepping down in 2007. At 91, Barker participated in the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over hosting duties to Drew Carey. Despite his absence from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker appeared to be in good spirits.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was taken into custody by the Metropolitan Police on the 3200 block of D Street SE and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. The Secret Service revoked his security clearance and put him on leave. His arrest follows another misconduct case involving a high-ranking supervisor, and the Homeland Security Department's inspector general is investigating these incidents. Court records show Baldwin is to be arraigned Friday afternoon, but no attorney is listed for him.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to capture a close-up image of a hungry lion in Lahore's safari park. Saeed approached the lion, armed only with a camera, and managed to take a few frames from just 10 feet away. However, the sound of the camera's shutter alerted the lion, causing it to aggressively jump towards Saeed, who quickly scrambled into his car. Saeed later reflected that he wouldn't attempt such a close encounter again.

The New York City Police Department has released images of a tattoo found on the body of an unidentified woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, who died on a Brooklyn street nearly a month ago. The woman, who was discovered unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in Gravesend, had a distinctive tattoo on her right leg featuring the name "Monique" etched across a tattooed ribbon within a heart topped with a rose. The NYPD is still awaiting a medical examiner's report to determine the cause of death and is asking anyone with information to contact Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, wood and steel home on the back of a flatbed truck after living in the UK. They purchased a 1986 Hino flatbed and spent a year and a half constructing their home, which now allows them to live almost self-sufficiently in Nelson, New Zealand. The home, costing about $25,000, features two bedrooms, a wood-fired stove, stained glass windows, and is powered mostly by solar panels, with gas-powered stove and hot water. The couple also plans to build another similar home in the future.

Research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class significantly outperformed their peers who either didn't use iPads or had their own device, with shared iPad students scoring around 30 points higher in early literacy tests. The study involved 352 students and suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than the technology itself, was the key factor in improved literacy. Blackwell recommends that schools reconsider how tablets are used, especially in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness. The findings are to be presented at the 65th annual conference of the International Communication Association in Puerto Rico.

A piglet born without hind legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters, balancing and foraging for food, and has captured the hearts of thousands, with villagers flocking to see it and its siblings.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone's car during the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana. Dracone, who had come in for tires and fuel on lap 25, spun out and clipped Phillips' leg. Phillips was treated at the infield care center and released after receiving stitches for his cut. The race was affected by rain, causing many cars to struggle with traction, and Dracone finished 23rd.

Horrific CCTV footage shows Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdering his wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her in the face five times. Severiano confessed to the murder, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. Cicera, a dancer in the dance troop Jaula das Gostozuedas, was found on the ground after the attack. Severiano, who had only been married for four days, stole a neighbor's car during his escape but was arrested by the police. The police found four handguns, a shotgun, and a bulletproof vest in his car. Severiano now faces life imprisonment.

Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," shared her personal struggle with mental illness, including anxiety and thyroid disease, which led her to believe her life was not worth living. She felt isolated due to her lack of a family and the pressure of societal expectations. Wilson now recognizes the link between depression and anxiety and advocates for acknowledging this connection to better address the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women. She urges those in need to seek help from Beyond Blue.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after striking her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014. Curtin, who was seven months pregnant at the time, found her ex-girlfriend using heroin in the bathroom and, after asking her to leave, beat her with a crowbar. The charge was dropped by prosecutors, who deemed Curtin's actions as "completely justified" due to the ex-girlfriend's history of harassment, threats, and attempts to drag Curtin's boyfriend back into heroin addiction. Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents. If convicted, she would have faced a mandatory prison sentence of nearly six years.

A pit bull named Gemma, who lives with two children in California, was filmed being fed treats but showed disgust when her owner tried to trick her into eating broccoli, which she spit out. The video aims to encourage the children to eat their greens.

HSBC has issued an apology after a link on its official website mistakenly directed visitors to a pornographic page. The error occurred because the URL address, which would usually connect to a third-party website, transferred visitors to the porn business. The bank removed the hyperlink and stated it had no association with the external site, assuring the public that its website remained secure. The incident involved a page for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which had been scrapped in 2011 and the site had been allowed to retire.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy, Marcus, provided firefighters with instructions during a 911 call, leading to the rescue of himself and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, from a fire at their home in Clinton. The fire started on the first floor, trapping the siblings in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus, who remained calm during the 11-minute call, guided the firefighters through the house, including breaking a window, to reach the children. He also comforted his sister during the ordeal. The siblings were taken to a children's hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other family members escaped on their own. Marcus's actions were described as heroic by the assistant fire chief.

Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured stunning images of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Jervis Bay on Australia's east coast, creating a "beautiful supernatural scene." The glow, caused by the single-celled phytoplankton noctiluca scintillans, is a natural defense mechanism. Similar displays have occurred in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and oceanography expert Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the algae typically blooms in spring and autumn due to natural causes.

New tests, like endopredict, can identify genetic markers in breast cancer tumors to assess the risk of recurrence, potentially sparing some patients from chemotherapy. These tests, which can cost around £2,500, are not yet widely available on the NHS but may be considered for use due to cost savings from avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy. The tests can help patients make informed decisions about their treatment, as demonstrated by a case where a patient's low recurrence risk meant chemotherapy was not needed.

Over the past nine years, more than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from HMS Illustrious. Eighteen other ships, such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, also had emergency evacuations. A strict "no touching" rule at sea suggests the women conceived before boarding or during leave. This data emerged nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was replaced following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have been serving in the Royal Navy since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. Additionally, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan due to pregnancy, with 99 servicewomen flown back between 2006 and 2013. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and most babies would have been conceived before the mothers left the UK, though some may have become pregnant on tour.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The discovery coincided with the approval of a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant, a move unpopular among many Japanese due to safety concerns. The drone, equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing cesium, was spotted by a staff member and investigated by police. Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga expressed concerns about future terrorism attempts using drones, especially around major events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The government will review drone operation regulations to prevent terrorism. Abe was not in his office at the time, attending a conference in Indonesia.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from China, takes care of his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's disease by riding her on the back of his motorbike to work every day. He ensures her safety by tying a sash around their waists and checking on her at work. His mother, who used to get lost when left alone, now feels safe and cared for, and Lu feels a sense of duty to reciprocate the care his mother once provided him.

A major study by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health, found that heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans increased by 17.2% between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. The CDC defines heavy drinking as more than one drink per day for women and two for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more for men. The study, which tracked adult drinking patterns at the county level, found that women’s binge drinking rates rose by nearly 36% in Santa Clara County, California, compared to 23% among men. Nationwide, the rate of binge drinking among women increased more than seven times the rate among men. The study also noted that 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers in 2012. The increase in drinking is attributed to changing social norms, economic factors, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study analyzed data from about 3.7 million Americans aged 21 and older.

The World Health Organization (WHO) and the UN's public health agency warn that doctors are performing unnecessary caesarean sections, putting women's and babies' health at risk. The WHO recommends that only 10-15% of births should be caesarean sections due to the associated dangers and costs. The current rate in England has more than doubled since the 1990s, with a significant number of women opting for planned caesareans due to anxiety about natural birth. The WHO statement contradicts NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans for women with tokophobia or other specific conditions. The WHO emphasizes the risks of complications, disability, or death, and the financial burden on the NHS.

Michelle Filkins, a 44-year-old woman from West Wareham, was arrested for allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' items in a yard sale. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. Filkins was discovered by the homeowner, Mark Conklin, on April 17, and fled in a gray Nissan pickup truck when confronted. Police found a broken window and a blanket covering it. Filkins attempted to re-enter the home, thinking Conklin had left. A construction worker reported seeing her with the stolen items. The police are asking anyone who received items to return them, as they are considered victims and can seek restitution through the court. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A lost iPhone was returned to its owner, Bella Crooke, after police posted humorous photos and messages on her Facebook page to track her down. The phone, which Bella lost at a friend's birthday party, was handed in to Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. Police used the phone to post selfies and puns, including a photo of the phone in a holding cell, to reassure Bella. Bella didn't have to give her name when she reclaimed her phone, as officers recognized her from her Facebook page. Bella has since put a password on her phone and thanked the police for their humorous approach.

A five-day-old baby hippo was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The mother watched in horror as the calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface, eventually dying hours later. The mother believed it was safer to stay with her herd, but this decision proved fatal for the baby. The mother tried to rescue the calf, but the sub-adult hippo had already grabbed it. The mother attacked the hippo on the neck, causing the sub-adult to bite down harder and fling the baby into the air, leading to its death. The exact motive behind the attack remains unknown.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on sale for £575,000, but it has just three years left on the lease. The property, described as bright and well-proportioned, requires renovation and is valued at £6 million if the lease is extended. The current freeholder is the Welcome Trust, and lease extensions could cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. The area, built in 1893, is known for high-status residents and rare short-lease properties. Potential buyers are advised to check their lease terms carefully.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage affecting 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, leading to baristas giving away free drinks. The issue, which began in the early evening on the East Coast and late afternoon on the West Coast, was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. Stores were expected to reopen for business as usual on Saturday. The outage also impacted Starbucks' evolution fresh and teavana stores. Despite the inconvenience, many customers shared photos and expressed gratitude for the free drinks on social media. The incident occurred just one day after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings.

Terrorist training and radicalization activities are taking place in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. These locations are being used to radicalize Muslims, with individuals participating in ordinary community activities but with hidden motives. The Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit has noted that such incidents are not limited to cities. Historical connections to terrorism include the 1998 training of extremists in the Brecon Beacons and the 2005 involvement of two 7/7 bombers in whitewater rafting in North Wales. Community intelligence is crucial for authorities to identify and address these threats.

A juvenile female Omura's whale, a species feared extinct, was found on a remote beach in Western Australia, marking the first sighting in the region and the second in Australia. The whale, which was difficult to identify initially, was confirmed through DNA profiling. The discovery is significant for scientists, as little is known about the species, which is typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like Indonesia, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale's unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin, will be studied further. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for scientific investigation and potential public display.

Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, argues that a woman, specifically Hillary Clinton, should not be president due to hormonal influences, despite studies showing women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks. Rios' views reflect a broader bias against women in leadership roles, which is well-established and affects both men and women. The article also highlights the need to address gender bias in the workplace, noting that diversity benefits everyone and that women have historically faced significant obstacles to leadership positions. Rios' comments have sparked controversy, as they contradict the achievements of women in leadership, such as Kim Campbell, Canada's first female prime minister.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is auctioning off his extensive collection of over 200 antiques, including a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, early Victorian furniture, a painting of himself with a longbow, and various other items like books, swords, and crystal chandeliers, with the auction set to take place in Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, and has been on the run since failing to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead. Shemansky, who is already on parole for battery on law enforcement and has a history of bipolar mental illness, is believed to have been pushed over the edge by divorce proceedings. He was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication, and his estranged wife is preparing to protect herself in case he arrives at her home. Authorities are urging anyone with information about his whereabouts to contact them.

Eugene, USA, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships, a decision made by the IAAF Council to take advantage of a unique opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. This decision bypasses the usual bidding process, despite Eugene's previous unsuccessful bid in 2019, which was won by Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council believes this move will help the global development of the sport. The 2007 World Championships in Osaka, Japan, were also awarded without a bidding process.

Aspiring model Leonie Granger, 25, lured professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in a honey trap to steal his winnings, resulting in her 16-year jail sentence for manslaughter. Granger befriended Hassan, who showered her with gifts, cash, and trips, and used her good looks to gain his trust. After Hassan took her to his flat, Granger's boyfriend and accomplice entered, tied up Hassan, and killed him while searching for his hidden money. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter, while co-defendants Kyron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life imprisonment. Granger's actions were described as "pitiless and wicked" by the judge. The case involved multiple robberies and was captured on Granger's mobile phone. Hassan's family expressed that his death will "haunt them forever."

Cesc Fabregas, Chelsea's midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, with his form significantly dropping since a strong start. Despite captaining Spain in a 2-0 defeat to Holland, Fabregas remains a crucial player for Chelsea, who are aiming for the Premier League title. His durability is in question, but with nine games left, his performance could be pivotal for Chelsea's success. Fabregas' late-season slump is a concern, but a resurgence could help Chelsea clinch the title.

West Ham is close to signing Jamaican starlet Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a trial and spent two weeks training with the club's academy. Beckford, a 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United, is also in talks with clubs in Belgium and is considered one of the hottest prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium will cost as little as £289, aiming to fill the 54,000 capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

A police investigation into a brutal assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, was dropped just three months after the incident, despite evidence pointing to the attackers. Lane, 40, was beaten by balaclava-clad protesters armed with iron bars on ropes during a hunt. The Wiltshire police have shelved the investigation due to insufficient evidence, leaving Lane and others dismayed. The attack occurred at Everleigh, near Amesbury, and Lane suffered a concussion, broken teeth, and memory loss. The police have not identified or charged anyone involved, and the countryside alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings.

Adam Gadahn, known as "Azam the American," was a U.S. citizen and prominent member of al-Qaeda, who spoke against the U.S. and urged attacks on American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January 2015. Gadahn, who converted to Islam in 1995, had a history of involvement with al-Qaeda, including being a chief English-language propagandist and appearing in videos threatening attacks on U.S. cities. He was indicted for treason and material support to al-Qaeda in 2006. Gadahn's final video called for Muslims to overthrow governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. He was married to an Afghan woman and had at least one child.

A five-year-old boy named Mai Zizuo from China, who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old, has gained fame for a viral video showcasing his impressive basketball skills, such as scoring multiple hoops and dribbling two basketballs simultaneously. His talent has earned him a large fan base in China, with netizens expressing amazement and even comparing their own skills unfavorably to Mai's. The video has sparked discussions and comments, with some fans feeling ashamed of their own abilities.

Tom O'Carroll, a former activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE) and a member of the National Council for Civil Liberties, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, who was previously jailed for corrupting public morals, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry. Hacked Off opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation, advocating for a statutory body to regulate the press. O'Carroll's involvement with Hacked Off is seen as an embarrassment due to his past with PIE, which campaigned for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained to host a Mercedes-Benz fashion week Australia catwalk, featuring a monochrome collection by ten pieces, designed to be worn in 20 ways, with models showcasing the unisex clothing in a unique setting.

Amir Khan, a boxer from Bolton, spent a family day at a safari park in Northern California, where he posed with giraffes, sea lions, and even fed a rare white tiger. He was joined by his wife, Faryal Makhdoom Khan, and daughter, Lamsa. Earlier, Khan announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, amidst speculation about other potential opponents.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, whose name was added to an Israeli memorial wall commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism, will be removed following complaints from his family and the organization Almagor. Abu Khdeir, 16, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, and his death is being described as a rogue attack, not a terror victim. The National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove his name from the memorial wall after his father's complaints, and Almagor has also removed his name from their website. A panel of judges began hearing evidence against the three suspects in Abu Khdeir's killing in January.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son repeatedly using the family cat as a makeshift pillow in the garden, which the cat eventually got tired of and wandered off indoors. Later, the boy and cat were seen playing and the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a former varsity basketball coach at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy, lost his job after testifying in a Philadelphia police corruption trial. Kushner, 32, is one of over a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government about police misconduct. He testified that undercover officers stole $81,000 in cash and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, Kushner was arrested again in 2011 and sentenced to four years of probation. He also pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Kushner believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges and maintains he never intended to deceive the school. He continues to coach in a Narberth summer league, where he is described as an excellent coach. Lawyers for the accused officers argue the government's case is based on false testimonies from 19 drug dealers and a rogue ex-cop.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a controversial chemical plant in China's Fujian province, which produces paraxylene, a carcinogenic chemical. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. Over 600 firefighters were dispatched to control the fire, which is now under control. The plant, located in Zhangzhou city, had previously been the site of an explosion in July 2013, but no casualties or toxic leaks were reported then. The construction of paraxylene plants has sparked protests in several cities in recent years, and the Zhangzhou plant had previously been relocated due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, Aston Villa's teenager, will continue to wear his socks low and use children's shinpads during his first Premier League start, due to superstition, despite Premier League referees' advice. His first league start came in a 3-3 draw against QPR, and he is pleased to have finally made it, hoping for more starts before the season ends.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive despite being out of a medically induced coma. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed sadness and hope for a miracle, while her father, Bobby Brown, claimed she was awake and watching him. An attorney for the family stated that her condition has improved, but the quality of her life will be uncertain for years. Bobbi Kristina is undergoing a long and difficult rehabilitation process.

Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point to defeat Germany's Sabine Lisicki, giving Russia a 2-0 lead in the Fed Cup final. Pavlyuchenkova had a tough time with her serve, committing 13 double faults, while Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were significant. The victory means Russia needs one more win from the remaining matches to reach the final and win their first Fed Cup title since 2008. Svetlana Kuznetsova also advanced by beating Julia Goerges in straight sets.

Residents of New South Wales are warned of more floods and damage as another storm, predicted to bring heavy rain from Thursday, is expected to hit the region. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that the clean-up efforts from the previous storm will be hampered, with over 4,000 jobs still to be completed. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which was severely affected by flooding and high winds. Weatherzone meteorologist Kim Westcott noted a trough of low pressure forming along the coast, expected to hit the far northern parts of the state. The Bureau of Meteorology indicated that the main impacts of the upcoming storm will be on coastal areas in the state's northeast, with heavy rainfall likely for southeast Queensland as well. The SES is urging residents to prepare their homes and families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's song "La Vida Loca," denied attempting suicide after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media reported she tried to take her own life, but Moric insisted she was treated in a hospital for a domestic accident. She posted photos of bruises on her Instagram, which she claimed were not entirely accurate. Moric, who was once married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, has a son with him. Corona was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, but Moric claimed he never blackmailed celebrities, only offering them the first option to buy photos.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times found that 12% of the British public would name Kate and William's second child Diana if it's a girl, with Alice and Charlotte as the next favorites. If the child is a boy, 13% would prefer James, with Alexander as the second choice. The poll also showed that 68% support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave.

A suicide bomber in eastern Afghanistan killed 17 people and wounded 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, during a protest against the provincial governor. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other organization claimed the attack. The incident occurred around 10 a.m. local time.

Dani Alves, a Brazilian right-back with seven successful years at Barcelona, is set to leave the club this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. Despite winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice, Alves and his agent, Dorinha Santana, have not agreed to a new deal, which would have required him to play in 60% of matches. The negotiations are now over, and the club has not considered renewing his contract.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old footballer, has requested Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors, Argentina. Osvaldo, who recently moved to Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, believes that Pirlo and Totti would be a good fit for the team due to their South American style and abilities. He also thinks that Boca Juniors fans would love to see them play at La Bombonera. Pirlo, a highly popular midfielder, and Totti, a legendary Roma player, are both considered by Osvaldo to be among the best in the world.

Amateur jockey Lee Lewis Ferguson, 18, sustained a cut on his nose after a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse during a race at Wincanton, watched by hundreds of thousands online. Despite the fall, Ferguson returned to riding and expressed no special treatment at Paul Nicholls' yard. He plans to continue racing and humorously suggested a potential gymnastics career post-racing.

James Haskell, a former London Wasps rugby player, posted an Instagram photo dressed as Iron Man from the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie, celebrating the film's release. Haskell, who has played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, has surpassed 100 appearances for the Wasps since his return in 2012.

The wide-leg trouser is a prominent trend in SS15, offering an alternative to skinny jeans. It can be styled in various ways, such as denim, cropped, printed, or striped, and can be paired with high heels to elongate the leg. Key tips include keeping the top half simple, choosing high-heeled shoes, and avoiding too much fabric. Brands like Gucci, Topshop, and Celine have showcased this trend, and it's a versatile addition to any wardrobe. For more inspiration, visit astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan will continue to screen "American Sniper" despite student objections and a petition against it. The film, starring Bradley Cooper, depicts a Navy SEAL sniper and has sparked debate due to its portrayal of the Iraq War. The university's decision to cancel the screening was criticized, and a counter-petition was created. The university's vice president for student life, E. Royster Harper, defended the decision, emphasizing the importance of freedom of expression. An alternative family-friendly film, "Paddington," will be shown for those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper." Michigan head football coach Jim Harbaugh praised the university's decision.

Two French tourists set an aerosol spray alight, causing a large flame to make contact with a quokka on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3. The quokka, a small animal similar in size to a domestic cat, survived but was singed by the flame. The tourists, aged 18 and 24, were evicted from the island and charged with animal cruelty, with their court appearance scheduled for April 17. Quokkas are native to small islands off the West Australian coast, including Rottnest Island and Bald Island.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old former dancer from the 1930s and 1940s, experienced her own performances for the first time through a video of "soundies," early music videos, shown to her at her nursing home by Mark Cantor of Jazz-on-Film.com and volunteers.

A study by vehicle leasing firm Osv found that a third of men in Britain have never washed their own car, with only 12% of those who do it regularly. The decline in car washing is attributed to factors such as shops opening on Sundays, more live football on TV, the rise of hand car washes, and the size of 4x4 and off-road vehicles. Car washing is most common in Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield, and least common in Oxford, Bath, and Edinburgh. Cars from brands like Audi, Toyota, and BMW are more likely to be washed by their owners compared to Range Rovers, Peugeots, and Mercedes. The tradition of men washing their cars on Sundays is fading due to time constraints and the availability of car wash services.

Steven Gerrard, Liverpool's captain, is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with a potential final against Arsenal on his birthday. Martin Skrtel, a former Liverpool player, praised Gerrard's impact on the team since 2008 and believes Liverpool can find suitable replacements for him. Skrtel, who was helped by Gerrard when he joined Liverpool, acknowledges that the team will be different without Gerrard but is confident in the club's potential to fill the void. Both Gerrard and Skrtel could return to the Liverpool lineup for the Villa match after serving three-match bans for violent conduct.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75, hit a hole-in-one during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, joining five other players in achieving the feat. Despite this, Camilo Villegas won the event with a total of five hole-in-ones, surpassing Nicklaus's achievement. Nicklaus, a six-time Masters champion and one of the five men to complete the career Grand Slam, is also a favorite for Rory McIlroy to achieve the same accolade if he wins his third major in succession.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms, with reports of twisters near Goddard and Aetna, and a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri. Other areas, including Wichita, Kansas, and the Mississippi and Tennessee river valleys, are expected to experience more storms on Thursday.

Robert Bates, an Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates was granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas, which the Harris family criticized as showing apathy. Bates, 73, was involved in a weapons sting operation when the shooting occurred. The Harris family alleges Bates was not qualified for the force but received preferential treatment due to donations and friendships. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denied these allegations, and Bates' lawyer released his training documents, claiming Bates had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2.

Conor McGregor, a 26-year-old Irishman, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11, 2023, in Las Vegas. McGregor has revealed a new tattoo of a tiger on his stomach, accompanied by the message, "If you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor, who has a gorilla tattoo on his chest, claims Aldo lacks the same motivation to win the title as he does. McGregor and Aldo have a contentious relationship, with McGregor asserting he has greater motivation to win the belt than Aldo to defend it for the eighth time. The two were on a promotional tour in Dublin when McGregor grabbed Aldo's belt and raised it in front of 5,000 supporters. McGregor will have a chance to legitimately hold the belt before his supporters in less than three months.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott was criticized for celebrating his masculinity by skolling a beer at a function, which anti-drinking campaigners argue glorifies binge drinking. Cultural studies professor Julie Robertson expressed concern that Abbott, who should be advocating against binge drinking, was instead promoting a culture where drinking is about quantity and speed rather than socializing. Opposition leader Bill Shorten and others suggested Abbott should set a healthier example. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott's actions, but Robertson highlighted the need for a shift in attitudes towards heavy drinking. Abbott's skolling was part of a speech to university players, which was met with cheers.

Indiana has seen a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases linked to Scott County, prompting Governor Mike Pence to consider extending a short-term needle exchange program. The program, which began on March 26, has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, with 1,400 used syringes returned. The Scott County outbreak, primarily among intravenous drug users using the high-powered painkiller OPN, has raised concerns about the future of needle exchange programs in other counties, as Pence opposes them as an anti-drug policy. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports that high rates of hepatitis C are a key indicator of needle-sharing and potential HIV outbreaks. The House approved a bill allowing needle-exchange programs in counties with the highest hepatitis C rates, but funding remains a concern.

Saskia took a football club knowledge test, scoring 87%, to impress her Arsenal fan boyfriend, who didn't dump her despite the test's challenging questions and his critical feedback. The boyfriend, who is a football fan himself, used the test to gauge Saskia's Arsenal knowledge, and she managed to keep him happy with her creative answers, earning an 'A' grade and avoiding a breakup. The test included questions about Arsenal's history, players, and positions, and Saskia struggled with some questions, such as naming the starting 11 squad and player positions. The boyfriend's actions were met with mixed reactions, with some praising his dedication and others finding it excessive.

Carlos Toro, a former DEA informant who worked undercover for 27 years, is facing deportation after retiring. Toro, who was a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel in the 1980s, fled Colombia and later worked for the DEA, providing information on his former bosses and associates. He was promised U.S. citizenship in exchange for his work, but this has not been granted, leaving him living in the U.S. illegally. Toro's fears of being sent back to Colombia are significant, as he believes he would be in danger. His work helped in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Toro is now in a precarious situation, trying to obtain a green card or passport to secure his future in the U.S. He is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl from Uttar Pradesh, India, allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village, set herself on fire using kerosene to protest the attack. She is now recovering in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident has sparked heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following a recent documentary on a similar case and other attacks. The accused men have been arrested, and the girl's death has led to protests and calls for more protection for women. The perpetrators were sentenced to death, and the case has drawn international attention to misogyny in India.

Louis van Gaal, Manchester United manager, has ruled out Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw from playing in the derby against Manchester City due to fitness concerns, despite both players being fit to play. Van Gaal aims for a victory to secure a high position in the table, avoiding a Champions League qualifying fixture later in the summer. He acknowledges the challenge posed by City and emphasizes the importance of controlling aggression, having lost the previous game to them. Van Gaal also looks forward to the derby atmosphere and appreciates the support from Manchester United fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium during a Premier League match, with empty seats and banners highlighting the £5.14 billion TV rights deal and the £64 cost for a ticket, calling for a reduction in prices to retain the fan base.

A newborn baby with a life-threatening liver condition, biliary atresia, was saved through a transplant from her twin sister, Shanell Reader, after her parents were deemed unsuitable matches. The baby, Star Reader, had been diagnosed with the condition shortly after birth, and despite an initial surgery to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant was necessary. Shanell, who was not a suitable match for her niece, offered part of her liver, leading to Star's successful recovery. The family had to undergo emotional turmoil, but the transplant has given Star a chance at a normal life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in Audi's football challenge, taking on Blues players Loic Remy and Willian. Hazard and Ake won the first two rounds, with Hazard and Ake winning the final round, taking a 6-0 lead. In the final game, Remy and Willian won, but Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the Audi cars, causing Remy to react dramatically. Willian was allowed to drive one of the Audi cars that were part of the football challenge.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the death of a pregnant couple and their unborn baby, claiming he was not suicidal during the crash, and faces 12 to 24 years in prison.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his hope that she would die in prison and criticized her lack of emotion during the sentencing. The judge noted that Spears suffers from a mental illness and described the crime as "unfathomable in its cruelty." Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, blaming the hospital for negligence. Prosecutors argued that Spears' social media posts about her son's medical issues were used as evidence. Spears, who had various medical problems, did not testify at the trial.

The Australian government will receive an improved influenza vaccine that includes protection against two new strains, H3N2 and B/Puerto Rico, which caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the US. The vaccine, which will be available from April 20, will be free for high-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the influenza specialist group, emphasized the importance of everyone getting vaccinated, as the modified version provides better protection against the strains circulating globally. He also advised people to book their flu shots now due to a delay in vaccine stock arrival.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could impact the management of the historic site. The criticism described the tomb as lacking historical character, while the state of Illinois, led by Governor Bruce Rauner, is considering merging the state historic preservation agency with another department. The tomb, which is a significant tourist attraction, has seen recent renovations and is in excellent condition, but the future of its management is uncertain due to financial constraints. The 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination coincides with these challenges, and supporters of the tomb are concerned about the impact of further budget cuts.

The passage discusses the resurgence of various fashion trends from the 1990s and 2000s, including chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, wide-leg 'rave' jeans, bucket hats, camouflage print, designer prints, double denim, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. It highlights how these trends are making a comeback, with celebrities and young stars like Rihanna, Kylie Jenner, Cara Delevingne, and Selena Gomez being mentioned as fashion-forward individuals who are embracing these retro styles. The passage also notes the original origins of some trends, such as the bucket hat and camouflage print, and their evolution over time.

A busy week of trending stories includes rainbows in New York, exotic dancers being banned in China, the Kylie Jenner lip plumping challenge, Alice Barker's time travel, a racially charged prom-posal, Ewan McGregor in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp in 'Black Mass', a pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombing his son.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career victory at the Miami Open, while Andy Murray received a cake for his 500th win. Williams advanced to the semi-finals after defeating Sabine Lisicki, while Murray pretended to eat a cake. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep beat Sloane Stephens. Williams' victory over Lisicki was seen as a form of revenge for her 2013 defeat at Wimbledon.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani advocate for free speech, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, was tragically killed in Karachi by two gunmen after she locked up her cafe, T2F, in Islamabad. Mahmud, known for her discussions on various topics including technology, street art, and politics, had become a symbol of non-violence and progressive values in Pakistan. Her death has sparked widespread grief and calls for justice, as she was seen as a beacon of hope for many, especially in the face of a repressive environment where free speech is dangerous.

Healer Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee from the partition of India, lives in a slum in Indian Kashmir, where he and thousands like him are hoping for citizenship rights after the Bharatiya Janata Party's victory in the state elections. Despite being born in India, Ram and the West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) are denied property ownership, voting rights, and state employment due to a pre-independence law that only grants citizenship to people born or descendants of those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. The WPRs, mostly from Punjab, live in poverty and are considered second-class citizens. The Bharatiya Janata Party is expected to champion their cause, but activist Labha Ram Gandhi warns that the community is ready to take matters into their own hands if their hopes are not realized.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is considering a move to Premier League leaders Chelsea, despite Chelsea's £4 million offer and Muto's desire to play regularly and develop his potential. Muto, who scored the winner against Shonan Bellmare, is still weighing his options, with Chelsea's boss Jose Mourinho acknowledging the offer and Chelsea's commercial interests playing a part in their transfer policy. Muto's former FC Tokyo boss, Ranko Popovic, praised Muto's potential and unique qualities.

The passage criticizes England's rugby team's policy of not selecting their best overseas players, arguing that it leaves them behind Australia, which has embraced this approach. It highlights the success of players like Matt Giteau, Drew Mitchell, and Steffon Armitage, who have thrived in France, suggesting that England's policy is outdated. The passage also mentions the improved performances of Nick Abendanon and Jonny Wilkinson after moving to France, reinforcing the argument for selecting the best players regardless of their club. The author concludes by urging England's coach Stuart Lancaster to reconsider his policy to ensure the best chance of winning the World Cup.

Firechat, an app that enables messaging without a web or mobile signal, has been downloaded over five million times and uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework to create local networks. Open Garden has developed Greenstone, an egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon to strengthen these off-the-grid networks, allowing messages to travel further than the 200ft limit of Firechat. Greenstone works with Firechat, has a one-year battery life, and can store up to 1,000 messages. Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to produce and sell Greenstone.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer, uses her Ted Talk to challenge the negative connotations of the word 'fat' and promote body positivity. She shares her own self-descriptors, including 'fat','short', and 'wife', and emphasizes that these terms are honest descriptions of her. Bustle argues that society's negative perception of 'fat' is harmful and that exposure to body diversity can lead to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. She also highlights the rise in size discrimination in the workplace and the importance of challenging societal norms. Despite some negative comments, Bustle's talk has received positive feedback and has helped her feel more confident in her body.

Theo Waddle, an Arsenal winger, has become a familiar sight on the bench for most of the season, despite being overlooked for the majority of the season. He has been pictured with his Arsenal teammates for a photoshoot with Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil. Waddle and his teammates, along with runway model Olga Sherer, posed for an official portrait for Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Waddle, who has been named on Arsenal's substitutes' bench for 17 of their 33 Barclays Premier League games, came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea. He hopes to make his first Arsenal start since their 3-0 win over West Ham on March 14, when Arsenal face Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

A collection of over 400 props and puppets created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker is set to be auctioned at the end of May at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on PropStore.com.
