Paul Merson criticized Andros Townsend for his call-up to the England squad, but after Townsend scored a goal for England, Merson admitted his mistake and expressed pleasure for Townsend's performance.

Chelsea has made a formal offer to FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, with the potential for him to join Chelsea's Dutch partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the move is completed this summer. The offer is not related to Chelsea's £200 million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, has 37 appearances and 16 goals, and 11 international caps for Japan. He recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree. Muto has not yet decided whether to join Chelsea, despite the honor of the offer. Chelsea's new shirt sponsor, Yokohama Rubber, will start from the 2015-16 season, and Chelsea is considering a two-week pre-season tour of Japan.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, potentially contributing to the obesity epidemic. The Finnish researchers compared the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-old children with records on antibiotic prescription, finding that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two. Boys who had taken antibiotics were also slightly taller. The study did not prove that antibiotics cause weight gain, but suggested that they may kill gut bugs that would normally feed on some of the food eaten, freeing up more food for the body and increasing appetite. The researchers warned of the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy. The study also noted that the over-prescription of antibiotics could be contributing to the development of excess weight problems.

A Buckingham Palace guard, while performing the Changing of the Guard, slipped and fell on a manhole cover, causing him to lose his footing, knock his bearskin, and drop his rifle. The incident, which was caught on camera by tourist David Meadwell, left the guard embarrassed as he quickly scrambled to his feet and realized how many people had witnessed the mishap. The guard is thought to have slipped due to the metal protectors on his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a daily event in the summer and every other day in the winter, performed by two detachments under the command of the Captain of The Queen's Guard. The Ministry of Defence did not comment on the incident.

The A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which originally had over 100 million viewers, to air in 2016. The new version will be co-executive produced by LeVar Burton, who portrayed Kunta Kinte in the original, and will be more contemporary, drawing from Alex Haley's classic novel. The remake will consult scholars in African and African-American history for authenticity and aims to reach both fans of the original and a new generation. The new "Roots" will be released in a time of racial unrest and will be seen by a new generation of viewers who have witnessed Barack Obama become the first African-American president and "12 Years a Slave" win the Oscar for Best Picture.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims that palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978. He was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member, leading him to leave the job immediately. Lawler's complaints were initially ignored, but he contacted palace officials again last year after learning about an investigation into alleged child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s. The police are now investigating his claims, and the Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with the investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song from '90s TV sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which features the couple rapping as they drive, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. In the video, Melissa raps about their friends' questions about parenthood and the couple's initial doubts about conceiving. At the end of the video, they share a sonogram of their unborn child. The video was made so loved ones living far away could know about the baby. The couple, who are the great-great-grandson and granddaughter of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, were surprised by the video's success. Jesse is also the great-great-grandson of Will Smith, the star of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' A similar pregnancy announcement video was made by a Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, couple last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind, featuring a black zigzag applique, was auctioned for $137,000. The dress, part of a private collection of over 300,000 pieces amassed by James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios employee, was bought for $20. The collection, which includes more than 150 items from the film, was sold at Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. Other notable items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. The film, which celebrated its 75th anniversary, was based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 best-selling book about a spoiled Old South socialite.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge, but was rescued by them before firefighters and paramedics arrived. The boy suffered minor injuries and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the boy's mother, and the exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera, which had been non-operational for over two years, was reactivated and pointed at a house in Birmingham, West Midlands, after all fixed devices were switched off in the region in 2013. The Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and plans to remove the camera, as it is part of a pilot program for digital technology, which does not include the Wellington Road camera.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas as part of the Jamaican team on May 2 and 3. Bolt expressed his happiness to be part of the team and his readiness to run. He also mentioned the successful tradition of Jamaica in relays and his commitment to making his country proud. The JAAA General Secretary, Garth Gayle, expressed excitement about Bolt's participation. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, Barcelona teammates, supported the club's basketball side by attending El Clasico matches, with Neymar also playing for Brazil in a 1-0 victory over Chile. Barcelona won the Euro League basketball contest, while Real Madrid remains top of their division. Neymar and his sister Rafaella, who also attended the basketball match, are part of Barcelona's efforts to compete for a treble of trophies. Neymar faced challenges from Chilean players during the match.

The Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 400 potentially missing after a ship carrying 550 people capsized in the Mediterranean Sea. The International Organization for Migration reported over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with 480 deaths recorded since the year began, often due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels. Most migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. The Italian coast guard has increased its rescue operations in response to the rising number of migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite acknowledging Liverpool's interest in Sanchez during Luis Suarez's negotiations. Sanchez, who has made an immediate impact in English football, netted 19 goals in the season. Wenger also downplayed speculation about a potential summer transfer of Liverpool forward Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record at London's Olympic Velodrome on June 7. Wiggins, who finished his Team Sky career in the Paris-Roubaix race, aims to surpass the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis. Tickets for the event will go on sale from April 19, and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports. Wiggins, who has a track pedigree including three Olympic gold medals, hopes to set a new British record and inspire others to challenge themselves.

Serena Williams, the twice French Open champion, experienced a tough match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, which she won 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, but was not pleased with the result. The US team was defeated 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske losing to Errani and Flavia Pennetta in the doubles rubber, leading to their relegation to World Group II. Williams admitted she was not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought, and the US team must work harder to return to the elite nations next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, who has struggled on loan at Manchester United, but a deal is complicated. Falcao, who scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate, is also in good form for Colombia, equaling the country's all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals. River Plate's vice president Matias Patanian has stated that the club dreams of Falcao and the doors are open for him to return.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has been announced as the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, including a glossy lustrous look and a half-pony, against a vibrant city background. The partnership was created by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring her single, Mirror Man. Henderson, who uses Batiste's dry shampoo regularly, expressed her excitement about the collaboration. The CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, who manages Ella, commented on the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

A billboard featuring officer Pablo Torres, who shot Aaron Siler, was erected in Kenosham, Wisconsin, causing shock and offense to Siler's family and friends. Torres, currently on leave, is under investigation for the shooting, which occurred during a car and foot pursuit of Siler, who was wanted on an active warrant. The billboard, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was intended to thank the community for its support, but has been criticized as disrespectful. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while the investigation into the shooting of Terry Knight, who was armed with knives, was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border, with three militants killed by Iranian forces. The militant group Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian group, claimed responsibility for the attack. Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving militants, who are believed to have crossed into Iran from Pakistan. The Pakistani government condemned the attack as an act of terrorism and is actively investigating the incident.

The classic video game "Space Invaders" from the 1970s has inspired a political discussion in Japan about UFOs. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani confirmed that Japan's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered extraterrestrial UFOs. Inoki, a former wrestler and lawmaker, asked about the ASDF's response to UFOs and if research is being conducted on alien visitors. Nakatani stated that fighter jets are scrambled if an unidentified flying object is detected, but no extraterrestrial UFOs have been found. Inoki also claimed to have seen a UFO, but did not know if aliens exist. This discussion follows a 2007 debate by former Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba on the legal implications of defending against an extraterrestrial invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was standing on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport collapsed, leaving him bleeding on the floor. He initially tried to avoid touching the seat due to cleanliness concerns, but was caught out when the toilet tipped over. Authorities believe the incident was an accident, and the man later changed his story to the police, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities have reminded people that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. The camera, which was traced back to Rebbie, had been used to film the girl and others over a four-year period. Rebbie faces several charges, including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The investigation began when the girl found the camera in March, and she reported that Rebbie had been watching her undress and molesting her from the age of nine until she was 13. Rebbie admitted to filming several victims, including other juveniles, and had specifically purchased the camera to record the now-15-year-old victim. The relationship between Rebbie and the girl's family is unknown, and his preliminary hearing is set for May 1. He is currently being held on a $500,000 bail.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest book, "Daughter and Salary Man," features a series of images where fathers leap into the air next to their daughters, who smile and look directly into the camera. The photos, which are part of a collection that translates to "Daughter and Salary Man," showcase fathers in sharply dressed suits performing energetic poses, with some older fathers displaying slightly pained expressions. The images, which are set against various Japanese landmarks, have garnered significant online interest for their unique and curious nature.

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has shifted attention to the county championship season, but focus returns to Kevin Pietersen, who is poised for a potential return to the England team. Pietersen, who was controversially axed in 2014, is now with Surrey, hoping to re-enter the Test set-up. He recently posed for a team photo at the KIA Oval, reflecting on his future with England, as Surrey prepares to start their campaign.

The Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to a poor run, despite his reinstatement the previous day by owner Angelo Massone. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender, was replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic after Ceahlaul was defeated 2-0 by FC Botosani, leaving them 16th in the standings and six points away from safety. Ze Maria had replaced Florin Marin in January and had a 25-match international career with Brazil.

Radamel Falcao, during his season-long loan at Manchester United, has struggled to perform at the level he achieved before a serious knee injury, and his former Monaco teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao is regretting the move. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been happier in Monaco, where he could have participated in the Champions League, as opposed to the less favorable conditions in France. Manchester United will need to pay £46 million to make Falcao's transfer permanent, but they are unlikely to do so as Louis van Gaal's side has only scored four goals in the season.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a man who robbed a Christchurch dairy using a distinctive cartoon mask. The tall offender, wearing a fluoro orange sweatshirt and oversized mask, stole the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The robbery occurred on Saturday, and the police are urging anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested for allegedly having sex with a 15-year-old student in her car on consecutive nights in January. She was previously arrested and suspended for having an inappropriate relationship with another 15-year-old student, which came to light after a school police officer learned of a possible relationship. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail for the second time and released on $50,000 bail. The school district has placed her on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being present on any Irving ISD property.

A video showing a large crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has been viewed over 500,000 times. New Zealander Tim Weston, holidaying in Puerto Vallarta, witnessed the crocodile holding the dog for hours in a public marina. The crocodile, part of a sanctuary 200m away, is a common sight in the resort, which is built among mangroves. Despite the crocodile's presence, the video has sparked horror and dislike among social media users.

Steve Bruce, manager of Hull City, is confident they can stay in the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 defeat by Southampton, with six wins so far in the season. Hull have six games left, including tough matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes Hull's struggles to long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton's James Ward-Prowse scored a penalty, and Ronald Koeman's team moved up to fifth in the table. Koeman plans to remind his team about following team rules.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching after he allowed students to change their SATs exam answers, leading to the annulment of the school's 2014 results. The local education authority's investigation found that Guffick had also altered some answers himself. Despite his claim that he only made answers more legible, the conduct panel deemed his actions dishonest but not fraudulent. Education Secretary Nicky Morgan's representative, Paul Heathcote, imposed a two-year prohibition order on Guffick, who was given 28 days to appeal.

Anders Lindegaard, a goalkeeper for Manchester United, is enjoying his life off the pitch with his stunning wife, Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots. They married in a beach wedding in Mauritius and have a son together. Lindegaard, who has struggled to make an impact at Manchester United, has been third-choice goalkeeper under Louis van Gaal and is now third-choice at Old Trafford. Despite his limited playing time, he has been linked with a move to FC Midtjylland, but the two clubs couldn't agree on a price. Lindegaard and Beqiri have been dating since 2012.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once illuminated Yankee Stadium in the Bronx failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite being valued between $300,000 and $600,000. The only bid came from a Sotheby's employee for $260,000. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, purchased the 10-feet-tall letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson, who bought the letters 'on a lark,' promised to visit the winning bidder in the U.S. to see the signage. The letters had been installed in 1976 and removed in 2008. Meanwhile, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has reminded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe of their professional responsibilities after they were caught smoking nitrous oxide and shisha pipes. Rodgers, who has Steven Gerrard available for the FA Cup semi-final, has not disciplined the players and wants to move past the incident. He emphasized the importance of understanding what is appropriate for professional athletes and stressed that setbacks are part of the journey to success. Rodgers' main focus is to lead Liverpool to their first FA Cup final of his tenure.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, is enjoying his time back in London after the international break, posting a photo of him relaxing with his dog. He performed well in the Euro 2016 qualifier, where Germany beat Georgia 2-0, and is now looking forward to the Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil, who joined Arsenal from Real Madrid in 2013 for £42.5 million, missed Arsenal's last game due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. He has been in good form since returning from injury, with four assists and three goals since January. Ozil claims he fits perfectly into English football, appreciating the lack of winter break and the opportunity to play many matches.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed satisfaction with Luis Enrique's performance as the team's manager, dismissing rumors of his replacement. Enrique, who took over the club last summer, is close to winning the La Liga title and has impressed with his work, particularly in preparation for games. Bartomeu highlighted Enrique's focus on La Liga and the team's potential to win three trophies, despite the club's contract with Enrique running until 2016. Barcelona's recent victory over Valencia in the Champions League, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, further demonstrated Enrique's impact.

Liverpool midfielder Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract, extending his stay at Anfield until 2020. His new deal, worth around £100,000-a-week, follows successful contract negotiations with Liverpool's vice-captain, Daniel Sturridge, and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, who joined Liverpool in 2011, has shown significant improvement under Brendan Rodgers and is now considered for the role of club captain, potentially replacing Steven Gerrard. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a full back at Chelsea, wants to stay with the club until the end of his contract despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He has struggled to adapt to the left back position at Chelsea but is happy there. Luis, who recently played for Brazil, is focused on Chelsea's Premier League title run-in, with manager Jose Mourinho emphasizing the importance of staying focused and winning every game.

Nathan Hughes' three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal, despite initial rulings of recklessness and a red card. The Wasps player, who had previously missed a Champions Cup match due to the incident, is now free to return to action, although he is unlikely to play in the upcoming Aviva Premiership trip to London Welsh. The appeal panel found no act of foul play, as the incident was deemed accidental.

Tim Durkan photographed and shared aerial shots of a fiery sunset in Washington, which was caused by wildfires in Siberia. The smoke from the fires, carried by atmospheric winds, filtered out shorter wavelength colors, leaving only red and orange hues, resulting in intense sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, the air quality will improve and the sunsets will lose their reddish hue.

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, was surprised when her stolen 2015 Ford Fusion was returned with new red rims and detailing after being recognized by a man who would return it to her. Instead of being upset, she thanked the thieves on Facebook and posted photos of her pimped-out car. She plans to professionally clean the vehicle and create a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who helped her.

Manchester City players risk losing £500,000 in bonuses if they don't qualify for the Champions League, as they are on incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. The team, led by Manuel Pellegrini, is currently fourth in the Premier League, just four points behind Liverpool, and must win a qualifying round to join the top three in the Champions League. The club has faced a series of losses, including early exits in the FA Cup and Champions League, and is now in a position where they must improve to secure their European spot. The defeat to Manchester United in the derby has put their Champions League hopes in jeopardy, and the team is also competing for world-class players like Paul Pogba. Manchester United's Louis van Gaal is confident of strengthening his squad in the next transfer window.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated City 1-0 in a'mini-derby' at Altrincham, with Callum Gribbin scoring the only goal from a free-kick. The match featured a predominantly English team, with 13 out of 22 players being English, and was held at Moss Lane with free entry. The game showcased the skills of both teams, with Marcus Wood and Marcus Rashford being notable players. The result leaves United two points behind Middlesbrough, with City having lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. The match highlighted the potential of homegrown talent, which FA chief Greg Dyke has expressed concern over.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised fellow Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon claimed his 147th cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who recently reached his 50th cap, expressed inspiration from Buffon's performance at 37 years old. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, also shared his pride in representing England and his ambition to continue playing well for his club and country.

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant, has partnered with Postmates to offer food delivery in 67 cities, starting with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. The fast-casual chain, which has previously declined third-party delivery services, is now joining Starbucks and Taco Bell in the food delivery market.

The parents of the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, Martin Richard, are urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber. They argue that the pursuit of the death penalty would prolong their suffering and that Tsarnaev should spend the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release and without the right to appeal. The sentencing phase for Tsarnaev is set to begin the day after this year's Boston Marathon. Martin Richard and his family were killed, and his sister, Jane, was severely injured in the bombings.

A Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet, custom-built for a mystery billionaire, has been transformed into a luxury home with bedrooms, lounges, a restaurant, and an onboard kitchen, costing £400 million and designed to accommodate dozens of guests.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station, but failed to land the rocket stage on a barge. Elon Musk, founder of SpaceX, stated that the rocket landed but tipped over. SpaceX aims to master sea landings to eventually land rockets on land, reducing space access costs. The Dragon will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, where the crew will spend about five weeks unpacking it. The Dragon will then return to Earth, guided to splashdown in the Pacific Ocean. This is SpaceX's sixth mission to the International Space Station, with the previous launch being scrapped due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at a new chapel of love in Las Vegas, launched in collaboration with NBC's Today show. The winning couple, announced next Monday, will marry at Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel inside the Westgate Hotel on April 23. Priscilla, who wed Elvis in 1967, will be in the audience, and the couple will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, and airfares and concert tickets. The chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit, requires couples to submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize. No impersonators are allowed.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can overtake Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United, where Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equaling the record for appearances in top European leagues. Henderson and Liverpool midfielder Joe Allen, who scored his first Anfield goal, expressed optimism despite recent poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Manchester City, currently four points ahead, lost 4-2 to Manchester United, giving Liverpool a chance to close the gap.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, securing Champions League places. Miralem Pjanic scored the opening goal in the 25th minute, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis saved multiple shots in the second half. The win moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli extended their winless streak to five matches. Security was tight for Napoli's first visit to Roma since a fan died in a previous season's Italian Cup final. Roma was without injured captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, but Pjanic made an impact with a free kick. Napoli had a potential penalty case, but it was not awarded. De Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half. Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne made his first action since a knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers' uninspired season in League One resulted in a 0-0 draw against Fleetwood Town, with the media team creating a 27-second highlight video featuring just the kickoff, goal kick, and final whistle, due to the lack of exciting moments in the match.

Roland Giroux, a man who uploads videos of his fish to YouTube, has a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid. He interacts with the fish by gently cupping it in his hand, massaging it, and even feeding it frozen blood worms. The fish, which was previously bullied by two other fish in its tank, has become more sociable and enjoys being stroked and played with by Giroux daily. The video concludes with the fish following Giroux's hand to the surface of the water, showing its clear affection for him.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery character, has returned to the England cricket team after a year of ups and downs, including a wrist injury from punching a locker. England's coach, Peter Moores, has advised Stokes to channel his aggression positively, as seen in his response to a clash with Marlon Samuels. Stokes' natural exuberance and desire to take on opponents are seen as assets, but they must be controlled to avoid pigeonholing him. England wants Stokes to play as much as possible to reach his full potential, and while there is a debate about playing two spinners, the team aims to let Stokes and Chris Jordan grow in the international game.

The Wales vs. Belgium Euro 2016 qualifier match at the Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out, with Wales in a strong position to qualify for a major tournament. Wales' 3-0 victory over Israel has raised expectations for the team, led by Chris Coleman, to secure one of the two automatic qualifying spots. Despite initial speculation, the match will not be held at the Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules, and the Wales squad prefers the Cardiff City Stadium. Real Madrid star Gareth Bale celebrated the victory, which propelled Wales to the top of Group B on goal difference.

England's Under-17 football team, led by coach John Peacock, has been named for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. The team, known as the Young Lions, are the defending champions and have a perfect qualifying record. They will face Italy, Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland in Group D. The squad features players from Premier League clubs, including Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold have also been recalled. The team's matches are scheduled for May 7, 10, and 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing Anderlecht's young talent, Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the best from their youth setup and has attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis turned down a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to continue his studies. Manchester City has been in talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to agree on a compensation package, with manager Manuel Pellegrini aiming to build for the future by acquiring Patoulidis.

A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with the death of Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender Mexican national who worked as an escort and was found strangled and beaten in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London. The man has been bailed and is to return to a London police station for further questioning. Scotland Yard is appealing to anyone who may have had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death. The police are not confirming if her profession was central to the investigation, but they are doing everything to solve the case. Vanessa had moved to London from Mexico and had spoken of her love for London and Paris on social media in the weeks before her death. The London Ambulance Service was called to the scene on March 28 at around 9.30pm.

Dawn, a woman who suffered seven miscarriages, accused her friend Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing £207 set aside for her babies' grave stone. After a lie detector test on The Jeremy Kyle show revealed Jamie's guilt, Dawn, who was going to spend the money on a gravestone, was left furious and felt betrayed. Jamie had sent a Facebook message confessing to taking the money but blaming it on his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed her distress and sadness, especially as she had only one baby to bury, Daniel James. She was comforted by her partner, also named Jamie, after the show.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women and children, who were previously killed, captured, and displaced by the terror group in northern Iraq. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders and the Yazidis were taken to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The exact reason for the release was not immediately clear. The Yazidis, a minority group of Kurdish descent, have faced persecution and were targeted by ISIS, which led to a major humanitarian crisis. An international coalition, including the United States, conducted airstrikes against ISIS in Iraq and Syria. The U.S. State Department estimates that 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq, making up less than 1% of the country's population.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation by Copa90 showcases his best goals and celebrations from the season, including his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane competes against Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, supports Brendan Rodgers' continued leadership of Liverpool despite a third consecutive season without a trophy, emphasizing the need for patience and the potential for improvement in the next season. Carragher, who has been recognized for his community work with a Beacon Award, also highlighted the importance of the right signings for the team's success.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport because it was deemed a security risk. The toy, a plastic nerf gun, was picked up on the X-ray system and security officers demanded it be handed over. The family, who were late for their flight, reluctantly complied. Upon returning from their holiday, they bought James a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and offered to post the confiscated toy back to the family. The airport defended its actions by stating that passenger safety and security are their top priority and that all regulations on security are set by the government.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife who loves pets, enjoys the outdoors, and fits his specific criteria, including being non-drinker and non-smoker, athletic, and independent. He promises benefits and is not shy of spending money on his partner.

Greg Dyke, FA chairman, is seeking support from five former England managers to implement changes in the Football Association, including increasing the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and redefining 'home-grown' to mean having trained in England for three years before the age of 18. The Premier League opposes these proposals. The former managers, Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, warn that blocking these changes could hinder England's progress in football and delay their World Cup victory. They highlight the shrinking pool of English talent at the top level and the need for more opportunities for young players like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, is now a mother in the show, with her pregnancy timeline being questioned due to the rapid progression from announcement to birth. Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is a popular character, but it seems his heart is not available for marriage. Fans have noticed the quick progression of pregnancies in the show, with one fan jokingly tweeting that if you are pregnant in Poldark times, expect to have it in the next 10 minutes.

Leicester City manager Nigel Pearson has advised his team to concentrate on their own performance and not be distracted by their relegation rivals, Swansea, as they face them in a crucial match. Despite a recent win against West Brom, which improved their chances of staying in the Barclays Premier League, Leicester remains at the bottom of the table. Pearson emphasizes the importance of focusing on their own game and maintaining realistic expectations, as overly optimistic predictions could pose a challenge.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a new record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous record held by a humpback whale. The journey, tracked by scientists from Oregon State University, also revealed Varvara's visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting that some western gray whales may actually be eastern grays. This finding could potentially lower the estimated number of western gray whales, which is believed to be around 150.

Residents on Hokkaido Island's east coast experienced a sudden emergence of 1,000ft of seabed, rising up to 50ft, due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The new coastline on Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu was discovered without prior indication, and authorities do not expect further expansion. The event is not related to the recent 7.8magnitude earthquake in Kathmandu.

Gregory van der Wiel, a Dutch full back for Paris Saint-Germain, has denied rumors of leaving the club in the summer. He expressed his love for the club, city, and teammates, and stated his happiness in Paris. Van der Wiel also mentioned his readiness to sign a new contract and his willingness to play whenever called upon. Despite being linked with Barcelona star Dani Alves, Van der Wiel insists he has no plans to leave PSG.

Carlos Tevez has been informed by Juventus to terminate his contract to return to Boca Juniors in Argentina. Tevez, a former Manchester City striker, has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer, and Boca Juniors is close to finalizing a deal for him. Tevez, who joined Boca's youth academy in 1996, has scored 26 league goals in 76 appearances for the club. Despite Juventus' reluctance to lose their top scorer, they have accepted Tevez's wish to leave and are looking for replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, believes any potential move would not affect Tevez's future, as he intends to finish his career at Boca Juniors.

Bayern Munich's manager, Pep Guardiola, ripped a hole in his trousers during a Champions League match against Porto, where Bayern won 6-1. The incident occurred during the excitement of the game, and Guardiola joked about needing new trousers for the next match. Despite the wardrobe malfunction, Bayern secured a place in the Champions League semi-finals, thanks to goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a brace from Robert Lewandowski. Porto, who had a two-goal lead from a previous match, was defeated by the Bundesliga giants.

A multi-vehicle crash involving ten people, including four children, occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, Brisbane. Three vehicles collided, leading to injuries such as chest and shoulder injuries, chest pain, arm injuries, and abdominal pain. Rescue efforts involved a helicopter and diversions were set up south of Fernvale. Six others with minor injuries or for further assessment were taken to Ipswich Hospital. The highway was closed for a few hours.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil is eagerly awaiting the Premier League match against Chelsea, counting down the minutes with his new Apple Watch. Ozil, who scored four goals in 25 matches this season, compared his watch to the TV character Michael Knight. The watch will be available for sale on Friday. Meanwhile, Arsenal's Jack Wilshere, who was sidelined for five months due to injury, is seen as the club's future by legend Ray Parlour, but his potential is hindered by his fitness record. Arsenal trails Chelsea by 10 points with six league games left.

Referee Mark Clattenburg, despite previous controversies, will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City, with City captain Vincent Kompany suspended for the match. Clattenburg has only sent off two players this season, both from United, and will be assisted by Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official. The derby could determine who finishes second behind Chelsea, with United currently leading due to a recent win streak.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of assuming embattled MP Billy Gordon would resign after being accused of domestic violence and admitting to his criminal past. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent, sympathized with Gordon's position and criticized the government's assumption, comparing Gordon to a "black puppet on a string." Gordon, who was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party, will remain in parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the government. Katter defended his statement, citing his personal experiences and criticizing the racial overtones of the government's assumption. He vowed that Gordon would not become a government puppet like other independents he mentioned.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, is using her dancing skills to challenge stereotypes and inspire others with her videos, aiming to change the representation of people with disabilities in media and society. She has also started motivational speaking at local schools.

Orlando City, coached by Adrian Heath, is interested in signing Javier Hernandez from Manchester United, who has struggled on loan at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a popular figure among Orlando's Latin-American fanbase, would be a significant commercial draw. However, eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, are also interested in the 26-year-old player. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord.

A gang of at least three people set fire to a car at a South Los Angeles gas station after an argument with the driver, who was filling up his white Dodge Charger. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, who managed to escape, but the car was completely destroyed in the process. No one was injured, but the incident is being investigated as an arson by the Los Angeles County Fire Department. The suspects remain at large.

A southern Iowa chiropractor, Charles Manuel, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for his services and performing exorcisms on patients. Despite his misconduct, he received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, with a perfect five out of five stars. Manuel must prove that the circumstances leading to the revocation of his license no longer exist before he can resume practicing. He is prohibited from applying for reinstatement for at least 10 years.

A U.S. reconnaissance plane, the RC-135U, was intercepted by a Russian SU-27 Flanker jet in international airspace north of Poland, which the U.S. described as "unsafe and unprofessional." The incident involved aggressive maneuvers and a high rate of speed by the Russian pilot. The U.S. denied claims that the plane's transponder was off, and the Pentagon plans to file a diplomatic complaint with Russia. This is not the first such incident, as a similar event occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, secured in a case with padlocks and chains, was stolen from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot just before President Obama's visit to Utah. The thief broke the car's window, used a rope or cable lock to free the rifle, and stole the agent's gear bag, backpack, and some clothing. The rifle's serial number was entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified about the theft. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle has not been recovered.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in 2012, allegedly while suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen examined Costa and found evidence of his declining mental state leading up to and during the incident. Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as a not guilty verdict could be returned if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack can be proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in a 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines having a better penalty record, and Barkley's shot was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton.

Two passengers on a Holland America Line cruise ship in Puerto Rico were found dead in their stateroom, leading to suspicions of murder-suicide. The ship, ms Ryndam, had departed from Tampa, Florida, on a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was in San Juan, Puerto Rico, at the time. The FBI and other authorities were notified and are investigating the incident. The cleaning staff discovered the bodies after knocking on the door. The cruise line is cooperating fully with the investigation.

Former Holland forward and assistant coach Patrick Kluivert has led Curacao to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF for the 2018 World Cup, after advancing with a 4-3 aggregate win over Montserrat. Kluivert, who has a personal connection to Curacao, previously played in the 1998 World Cup and assisted Louis van Gaal in 2014. Curacao will next face Cuba on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, a former Inter Milan and Real Madrid player, believes that helping Leicester City stay in the Premier League will feel like winning a trophy, as he has won all major European competitions. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic, stating that he believes they have a chance to avoid relegation. He signed for Leicester in the summer, leaving Italy after ten years, and is currently a key player. Cambiasso is also considering staying beyond his current one-year-deal.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma, who has two children under five, is at risk of being banned from seeing them by her mother, Debbie, due to Gemma's refusal to stop drinking, partying, and suspected theft. Gemma handed the children to Debbie when they were four months old, and Debbie, who cares for the children, is threatening to ban Gemma from the house and seeing the children because she can't trust her. Gemma admits to stealing money and other items from her mother in the past, but denies stealing an iPad from one of the children. Debbie, who appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show, says Gemma's lifestyle choices, including drinking and partying, are getting out of hand. Gemma has also been unemployed and has a history of underage sex and drinking since the age of 13.

Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored a goal after Chelsea captain John Terry's strong challenge on Manchester United's Radamel Falcao led to a loose ball, which Fabregas passed to Oscar, who then assisted Hazard's goal. Sky Sports pundits, including Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness, agreed that Terry's tackle on Falcao was a foul and should have been penalized. Henry expressed sympathy for Falcao, while Redknapp acknowledged that Falcao could have done better to stay on his feet, but Terry's challenge was still a foul.

Hillary Scott, co-lead singer of Lady Antebellum, was evacuated safely from her tour bus after it caught fire on Interstate 30 in Texas. The bus, which belonged to the country band, stopped after a rear tire blew out, and the fire started after everyone had left. The bus was destroyed, except for Scott's Bible, and the band's other members were not on the bus at the time. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr Adrian Quarterman, a Scottish scientist, is developing a space laser that could convert sunlight into energy to power homes, with potential applications in Scotland and disaster-stricken areas. The laser, which is not as powerful as those depicted in science fiction, uses satellites with mirrors to harvest sunlight and convert it into laser light, which is then sent back to Earth. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and Dr. Quarterman plans to move the trials to Portugal. However, he acknowledges the need for control over the satellites to prevent potential misuse.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of sexual offences against children, has escaped from a psychiatric unit in Hampshire. Munden, who has a learning disability and was previously sentenced for sexually touching a three-year-old girl, was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire. He is described as 5ft 8ins tall, of a heavy build, and has dark hair. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act and is subject to a hospital order. The police are conducting a manhunt and have released images of him with and without a beard. Munden was also convicted of possessing indecent images of children and had items related to children found at his home.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to pay back over $2.6 million in gifts after Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, Donald Sterling's wife, sued her. Shelly claimed Donald used their money to buy Stiviano luxury items and helped her get a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with the gifts. The court decision is seen as a victory for the Sterling family and sets a precedent for recovering damages from recipients of ill-gotten gifts. The lawsuit followed an audio recording of Donald Sterling making racist remarks and criticizing Stiviano for her social media posts. NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banned Sterling from the league, fined him $2.5 million, and terminated his ownership rights in the franchise.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player, criticized Arsenal's transfer window decisions and suggested the club needs to sign four top players, including a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker, to win the Barclays Premier League title. He also questioned Olivier Giroud's ability to lead Arsenal to victory, despite his 14 league goals this season. Henry cited Chelsea's successful league win last season after signing Thibaut Cortouis, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example. Arsenal is currently third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand. Henry emphasized the need for Arsenal to be competitive within the group to win the league.

A young woman, a victim of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, has shared the severe impact of his actions on her life in court. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who is scared for her future relationships, expressed her fear and confusion about why she was targeted. She also revealed that she had attempted suicide since the abuse was brought to light. Van Ryn, who is now in custody, remains a concern for the victim, who worries about his potential release and the lasting effects of his abuse. The hearing continues.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is making a return to the first team after more than a year due to a serious knee injury. He has been feeling 'better and better' and is currently playing for Arsenal's development squad, having not featured for the first team since March 2014. Gnabry, who impressed for Arsenal last season, is now over his injury worries and is looking forward to the next game.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling 70ft down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, after running from a taxi to avoid paying the fare. He had caught the cab after a night out with friends but didn't have enough money to pay. The taxi driver, Dave Sidaway, said he stopped because he couldn't see where he was going and didn't know the danger. Phillips was discovered dead the next day by a dog walker. The inquest recorded a verdict of accidental death, stating Phillips likely became disorientated and didn't know the danger. He worked for Pretty Green, a clothing label run by Oasis star Liam Gallagher, and had grown up in Barry, South Wales. He had planned to stay with a friend but didn't have enough money to complete the journey, so decided to trick the driver by dodging the fare. He fell down the cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade, also called The Dardanelles.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer's passport delay received no compensation, while managers at the passport agency, which made a £42 million profit, received up to £3,500 in bonuses. The Home Affairs Committee chairman, Keith Vaz, expressed astonishment at the lack of compensation, especially given the profit made by the passport office. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved, totaling £203,066, with an average payout of £92.68. The Passport Office could not disclose the number of rejected claims due to a system failure. Ministers refused to compensate all affected individuals, citing the creation of a precedent. Among those refused were Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham, who lost nearly £1,500 on a trip to Morocco due to delayed passports. Managers received bonuses averaging £499, with the highest being £3,500.

A 1930s semi-detached home in Horfield, Bristol, with original features like stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, and vintage food tins, is up for auction. The property, which has remained unchanged for over 80 years, includes a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, and original 1930s kitchen cupboards. Despite some upgrades, such as double glazing, the cost of renovations may deter developers. The house, with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000, will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup for Alex Smith but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Smith's concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, but they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
"Soul Food" is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice, born in New Orleans, lived in New Orleans, Texas, and San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike (I-95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 (NY 495) inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast via NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London, formed Blur in Stanway School, drawing influences from various music genres, achieving worldwide success with their self-titled debut album in 2001. Albarn's solo album, Everyday Robots, released in 2014, featured collaborations with notable artists and sampled Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, housing many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut EP, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

Shooter (2007 film) follows Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger (Mark Wahlberg), framed for murder by a rogue private military company. Shooter (TV series) stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile, who is drawn back into action after discovering a plot to kill the president.
"House (also known as House, M.D.) is an American medical drama that aired on Fox for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012."

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including Sharon Tate, at his instruction. He also received convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After his charges, recordings of songs written and performed by Manson were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn, born on August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist. He began his acting career on television with a brief appearance in "Little House on the Prairie" in 1974. Penn gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas such as "At Close Range" (1986), "State of Grace" (1990), and "Carlito's Way" (1993). He became a prominent leading actor with "Dead Man Walking" (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations for "Sweet and Lowdown" (1999) and "I Am Sam" (2001), and won his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for "Mystic River" and a second one in 2008 for "Milk".

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001, was an Australian cricketer renowned as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he held a leading role in cricket for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held significant leadership roles in the music industry, including chairman and CEO positions at Epic Records (a division of Sony Music Entertainment), Arista Records, and the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with Rage Against the Machine (1991-2000; 2007-11) and Audioslave (2001-07). He began his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991. As of 2016, he is part of Prophets of Rage, a band featuring members such as Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine is a German heavy metal band formed in 1984 by Peter "Peavy" Wagner.

"The Millers" was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning 34 episodes over two seasons. The show was canceled on November 14, 2014, after four episodes of its second season.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933-2006) was an American politician and the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, a Democrat known for her outspoken feminism. She first gained national attention as the state treasurer of Texas, delivering the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. Ann Richards (1935-1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled "A Reminder" independently in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film directed by Stephen Verona, written by Verona and Leigh Chapman. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, was born on July 6, 1927, and passed away on October 3, 2004. She wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan leader who played a key role in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as independent nations from Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is a vaguely defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished under mysterious conditions.

Colin Kaepernick started as a backup for Alex Smith in the 2012 season, became the 49ers' starter after Smith's concussion, led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, and in his first full season as a starter in 2013, helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a nonpersonal, openly sponsored marketing communication that promotes or sells products, services, or ideas through various mass media, including traditional media like newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as new media like search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
"Private Lives" is a 1930 comedy of manners by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle, an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist, was born in Stagira, Chalkidice, and joined Plato's Academy in Athens at 17 or 18. He stayed there until 37, then left Athens to tutor Alexander the Great at Philip II of Macedon's request in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born on February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson, a point guard for the Lakers, played for 13 seasons, won multiple championships, and was named one of America's most influential black businessmen. He retired and returned to play for the Lakers before retiring for the third and final time. Johnson also had numerous business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in 1994 in Los Angeles, California, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They released three albums and gained popularity in 1997 with their television series and support for large rock acts.

James VI and I (1566-1625) was King of Scotland as James VI from 1567 and King of England and Ireland from 1603 until his death. He ruled both Scotland and England in personal union, advocating for a single parliament. He achieved most of his goals in Scotland but faced significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Morgan Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000. Bentley, famous for his Geordie accent, left Channel 4 in July 2011 to continue narrating the revived Big Brother on Channel 5.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony-Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest and the sixth most populous of Germany's sixteen states, with an area of 18,413 km² and a population of 4 million. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is known for its quality wine, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and the only two in former East Germany.
East End Park is a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, and "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" alongside Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

"Mohra" is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah, with Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad, and Sadashiv Amrapurkar in supporting roles. Originally, Divya Bharti was considered for the lead role but passed away, leading to Raveena Tandon replacing her. The film, released on July 1, 1994, became the second highest-grossing Indian film of the year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. It is also known for its chart-topping songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, featured on singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, famous for writing the 1987 action film "Lethal Weapon" and directing his debut film "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang" in 2005.
"A View to a Kill" (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film, the seventh and final one starring Roger Moore as the fictional MI6 agent James Bond."

Papua, Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, includes most of western New Guinea. It was previously known as Irian Jaya, West Irian, or Irian Barat, and encompassed all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus, who likely died of natural causes, had unconfirmed rumors suggesting his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez entered the music industry in 1999 with her debut album "On the 6," which included the hit single "If You Had My Love." She became the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week with her second album "J.Lo" and the film "The Wedding Planner" in 2001. Her third album, "This Is Me... Then" (2002), was influenced by her high-profile relationship with Ben Affleck. She later married Marc Anthony and regained prominence with her role as a judge on "American Idol" and the hit single "On the Floor" in 2011.

A working animal is a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks, ranging from family assistance like guide dogs to jobs requiring tractive force, milking, or herding. Occasionally, wild animals are trained for novelty or entertainment, but they lack the trustworthiness and mild temper of true working animals.

"Billboard Dad" is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. Top Latin Albums is a Billboard magazine record chart for Spanish language full-length albums in the American music market, and The Regional Mexican Albums is a genre-specific Billboard record chart published weekly in the United States.

Vedam is a 2010 Telugu language Indian drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, starring Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
"Men in Black II" is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in the 1605 novel Don Quixote by Spanish author Don Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra. He serves as the squire to Don Quixote and is known for his humorous, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit, referred to as sanchismos.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role, directed by Ron Underwood.
Hedda Gabler, a play by Ibsen, premiered on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich, with Ibsen present at the event.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth is an English actor and director, born on May 14, 1961.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., commonly known as Juve, is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, Piedmont, founded in 1897 by young students, including Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy after Genoa's football section, established in 1893. The club traditionally wears a black and white striped home kit since 1903 and plays its home matches at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in films and TV series in the late 1990s and early 2000s, including "Kate & Leopold" (2001), "Far from Heaven" (2002), and "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit."

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress, known as the world's most famous adult entertainment performer and "The Queen of Porn." She began acting in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamor model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a member club of the National Basketball Association (NBA), competing in the Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and later pay-per-view, organized by the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW). It was traditionally held on Thanksgiving and Christmas from the 1960s to the 1980s, mostly at Greensboro Coliseum. The 1985, 1987, and 1997 Starrcade events were produced by Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) under the NWA banner, with the 1997 event being the fifteenth annual Starrcade pay-per-view event.

Jack Ryan Falahee is an American actor, recognized for his roles as Connor Walsh in the ABC legal drama "How to Get Away with Murder" and Benjamin Stringfellow in the PBS historical drama "Mercy Street."

"Don't Say No" is the debut extended play by South Korean singer Seohyun, who debuted as a member of Girls' Generation in 2007. She has also established herself as an actress, notably through her participation in stage musicals. Seohyun debuted as a solo artist with "Don't Say No" on January 17, 2017, making her the third Girls' Generation member to debut as a solo artist.

The Apple II is an 8-bit home computer, one of the first successful mass-produced microcomputers, designed primarily by Steve Wozniak with Steve Jobs overseeing the development of the case and Rod Holt developing the power supply. It is a family of home computers, one of the first highly successful mass-produced text command microcomputers, introduced in 1977. Stephen Wozniak, also known as "Woz," is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur who co-founded Apple Inc.

A&E is an American cable and satellite TV channel, the flagship of A&E Networks, a joint venture between the Hearst Corporation and Disney's ABC Television Group, with both companies holding a 50% ownership stake.

L.A. Reid has held significant leadership roles in the music industry, including chairman and CEO positions at Epic Records, Arista Records, and the Island Def Jam Music Group, as well as founding Hitco Music Publishing and co-founding LaFace Records.

Veeram (Valour) is a 2014 Indian Tamil action film directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, while Veeram (Valour) is a 2016 Indian epic historical drama film written and directed by Jayaraj.

"Home for the Holidays" is a 1972 American made-for-television horror film directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling, and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter, and Walter Brennan. It premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972. The 1995 film version stars Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Taran Hourie Killam, born on April 1, 1982, is an American actor, comedian, and writer.
The Sex Factor is an online reality TV series produced by xHamster, featuring eight men and eight women competing to become porn stars.
John Hovig Dolmayan, born on July 15, 1973, is a Lebanese-born Armenian-American songwriter and drummer.

"Weekly Idol" is a show hosted by Jeong Hyeong-don, a comedian, and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal, a rock music genre, emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s, primarily in the UK and the US. In the late 1970s, bands like Iron Maiden and Saxon continued the trend in the new wave of British heavy metal.

Ashton Kutcher, known for his role in "Two and a Half Men," also starred in romantic comedies such as "Guess Who" (2005), "A Lot Like Love" (2005), "What Happens in Vegas" (2008), and "No Strings Attached" (2011).

Conrad Dunn started his screen career with the role of Francis "Psycho" Soyer in the 1981 film Stripes, which also featured John Larroquette, John Diehl, and Judge Reinhold in their first significant film roles.

Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy TV series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro, produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. Other indigenous and Christian ethnic groups, such as the Assyrians and the Ottoman Greeks, were similarly targeted, and their treatment is considered by some historians to be part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist, born on 4 October 1967.

William Jefferson Clinton, born on August 19, 1946, is an American politician who served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001. His first inauguration took place on January 20, 1993, at the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle, an English director, producer, screenwriter, and theatre director, is known for films like Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours, and Steve Jobs. The film "Miracle at St. Anna" is set in World War II, Italy, focusing on four Buffalo Soldiers from the 92nd Infantry Division who find refuge in a Tuscan village and bond with the locals. Mendicant religious orders, such as Catholic mendicants, Hindu ascetics, Sufi dervishes, and Jain and Buddhist monastic orders, follow a lifestyle of religious asceticism. Monks, who may live alone or with others, dedicate their lives to serving all living beings, prayer, and contemplation, often choosing to leave mainstream society.

Arizona, the 48th and last contiguous state to join the Union in 1912, is the 6th largest and 14th most populous of the 50 states. Approximately one-quarter of Arizona is made up of Indian reservations.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson, born on April 15, 1990, is a French-British actress, model, and activist. She was born in Paris and raised in Oxfordshire. She attended the Dragon School and trained as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett started her film career in the mid-1980s, after obtaining a bachelor's degree in arts from Yale University and a master's degree in fine arts from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor is the highest award given by NASA, awarded by the U.S. President in Congress's name based on recommendations from NASA's Administrator. To receive this honor, an astronaut must achieve extraordinary accomplishments during space flight under NASA's authority. Frank Frederick Borman, II, a retired Colonel in the USAF, is an example of an individual who could be awarded this medal.

The Armenian Genocide, also known as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government's systematic extermination of 1.5 million Armenians, mostly Ottoman citizens within the Ottoman Empire and its successor state, the Republic of Turkey. Turkey, the successor state of the Ottoman Empire, denies the term genocide as an accurate description for the mass killings of Armenians that began in 1915.

The Quran, believed by Muslims to be verbally revealed by God to Prophet Muhammad through the angel Gabriel, was revealed over approximately 23 years, starting on 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40, and ending in 632, the year of his death.

The human brain, part of the central nervous system along with the spinal cord, consists of the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum. The cerebrum is the largest part, containing important structures like the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic structures (amygdala, hippocampus), claustrum, basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy drama film set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American family-oriented television network that offers a variety of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how-to, hunting and fishing, children's shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, born on August 27, 1908, and passed away on February 25, 2001, was an Australian cricketer widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time. Despite becoming reclusive in his later years, his opinion remained highly valued, and he was recognized as a national icon even 50 years after his retirement in 2001. Prime Minister John Howard called him the "greatest living Australian."

Margaret Hilda Thatcher, born on October 13, 1925, and died on April 8, 2013, was a British stateswoman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1979 to 1990 and Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990. He was the founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, which he directed for 30 years and produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood was also a renowned conductor, having worked with many leading orchestras worldwide. He held various academic positions, including at Harvard University, the University of Cambridge, and Cornell University. Hogwood was remembered for his generosity, academic brilliance, and his ability to reproduce historical music conditions. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service to be held later.

The report shows a decrease in homicide cases in Scotland, with 57 victims recorded by the end of March 2016, the lowest since 1976. A sharp instrument, mostly a knife, was the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides. 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or drugs.
