Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the need for continued efforts in education, enforcement, and community support to prevent violent crime. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker expressed caution, noting an increase in sexual crime and a 27% rise in violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland in the Premier League, marking the first time Sunderland defeated them this season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal of the season, while Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty contributed to Sunderland's win. Despite creating numerous chances, Bournemouth failed to score an equalizer, even after Steven Pienaar's dismissal. Head coach Chris Wilder emphasized the importance of moving on from the loss.

Mr Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, has stated that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to stop the boats carrying migrants. Australia detains these migrants and sends them to offshore processing camps for resettlement. The New York Times criticized this policy as brutal, inhumane, and at odds with Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Mr. Abbott also compared the Islamic State to the Nazis, a comparison that was strongly criticized by Australian Jewish groups. Despite the backlash, Mr. Abbott stood by his comments, stating he was not in the "business of ranking evil."

Washington accused Russia and the Syrian government of intensifying attacks on civilians in Aleppo, leading to the US halting talks unless Moscow stops bombing. The US suspended its participation in bilateral channels with Russia, citing Russia's failure to uphold commitments and targeting of critical infrastructure, including hospitals. Russia denied involvement in the aid convoy strike and expressed regret over the US decision. The US also planned to withdraw personnel and continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations in Syria.

The think tank Policy Exchange's report suggests that selling high-value social homes could raise £4.5bn annually, enough to build 80,000 to 170,000 social homes, potentially reducing the social housing waiting list by 500,000. However, Labour criticizes the proposal, arguing it would displace low-income families and worsen the housing crisis, while the government and housing minister support the idea as a way to increase social housing and reduce waiting lists. Critics fear it would lead to segregated communities and the loss of affordable housing.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died from a disease that has reached 942 cases in the city. The cause of his death, measles, could not be confirmed as the main cause by the initial examination. An inquest will be opened to allow further tests. Since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a rash a few days after being discharged. He was found dead at his flat on April 18. Public Health Wales confirmed a diagnosis of measles, but further tests are needed to determine the cause of death. The family was unaware of how Mr. Colfer-Williams contracted measles, as no close family member has it, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter.
Vincent Hudson, 54, has been charged with a historical offence of sexually assaulting a boy under 16, reported in 2001. He is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In a National League match, Gateshead and Guiseley ended in a 1-1 draw. Guiseley scored first in the 15th minute, but Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute. The match saw several substitutions, including Michael Rankine for Jordan Preston, Luke Hannant for Gus Mafuta, Adam Boyes for Jake Cassidy, and Derek Asamoah for Kevan Hurst. Simon Walton received a yellow card for Guiseley, and Wes York scored for Gateshead. The match began with Guiseley leading 1-0 after the first half, but Gateshead managed to level the score in the second half.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of a football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which is delayed due to a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed the club would start work at a shareholder meeting on Tuesday, with the work previously approved by Bristol City Council in November. The club aims to sign a section 106 agreement soon and hopes to proceed with redevelopment plans by May if no judicial review occurs.

Cuadrilla, the firm behind the tests, has suspended drilling after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, in Lancashire. The British Geological Survey (BGS) is examining data to decide whether to resume operations. Shale gas drilling, or fracking, involves shattering hard shale rocks underground to release gas. The process has been controversial, with concerns about potential environmental impacts. The BGS is also monitoring fracking as a precaution. The latest tremor, felt in Poulton-le-Fylde, shares a similar location and mechanism with the previous one. Cuadrilla is consulting with relevant authorities and experts before deciding on further actions.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, while denying three counts. He was cleared of the other two charges. Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and not collecting funds for the charity, and he had permission from the Hillsborough Justice Campaign to display the banner. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town won 3-0 against Queens Park Rangers, with goals from Grant Ward, Cole Skuse, and Tom Lawrence. QPR's Alex Smithies made a crucial error by miscuing a clearance, allowing Luke Varney to score. Ipswich's Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, while QPR's Ian Holloway expressed disappointment and emphasized the need for mental toughness. The match saw several saved shots and missed opportunities for both teams. Ipswich's win improved their league position, while QPR struggled to find the net.

Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, impressed in the T20 Blast last season by scoring 373 runs at a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's progress and the elite performance environment created by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win against Chinnor, 29-12, with key contributions from Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams. Despite Chinnor's strong performance, the Reds' coach, Churcher, emphasized the need for continued improvement and building on their recent success. In their upcoming eight games, the Reds will face seven teams below them in the table, including league leaders Old Elthamians.

A 28-year-old Bangladeshi man, Nazrul, also known as Nazu, was arrested in Kolkata for allegedly raping a 74-year-old nun, causing outrage and protests in India. This is the sixth arrest in the case, with eight suspects identified, two of whom are still untraced. Nazrul fled to Bangladesh after being identified from CCTV footage, but was arrested based on a tip-off that he was due to return to Kolkata. The attack also involved theft and ransacking of a convent school.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, discusses in an interactive video the reasons for changes in consumer purchases, such as the impact of domestic freezers, washing powder, and cheaper imports, and how brand ownership and rankings in the UK are evolving. The video is best viewed in full screen and a non-interactive version is available.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills was tricked by a scammer posing as BT technical support, who gained remote access to her computer to steal money. A similar scam occurred in Stranraer, seven days later, where a woman lost money to a caller claiming to be from BT technical support. PC Siobhan Pellett expressed concern over the ease with which scammers gain access to victims' computers and the substantial sums of money being stolen. She urged people to be cautious when answering cold calls from individuals seeking remote access to their computers and to never share banking details or account numbers over the phone, as reputable businesses and banks never request such information.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone to lead them in their final league game against Toulouse, following his departure from Swinton Lions. He replaced Stuart Littler, his former assistant, at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, including a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to a rider with head injuries and hypothermia at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The injured person was treated and then transported to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

The UN's World Radiocommunication Conference in Geneva decided to allocate a radio frequency for a global flight tracking system, improving upon the current ground-based radar system. This new system will allow satellites to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) transmissions from aircraft, enabling real-time tracking of planes worldwide. The decision follows the disappearance of flight MH370 in 2014, which highlighted weaknesses in the current air navigation system. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a deadline for adopting new tracking guidelines, including aircraft sending their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, a boy who disappeared at age five, was found at 18, living with his father in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested and charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. He is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio with a $250,000 bail. The FBI received a tip on October 30, 2023, that led to the boy's recovery, and his mother has been notified. Authorities suspected his father was involved in the disappearance around the time Julian said he was taking him to preschool in August 2002.

Firefighters spent several days at a site in Duncan Street after a blaze on 2 March, which caused travel delays and reduced train services. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, a firm run by Asset and Land Group, from accepting waste due to fire safety concerns. The firm, which had been broadly compliant with fire safety law, was unable to comment and has until 7 August to appeal the decision. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, after considering the fire's impact on residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills in Russia's lower house, the Duma, directly related to the situation in Ukraine. The first bill would allow Russia to accept a territory as a new "subject" of the Russian Federation if its people express a clear desire to join, without the need for a neighboring state to sign a treaty. The second bill aims to expedite the process of issuing Russian passports, removing financial and residency requirements, and allowing Ukrainians to apply for Russian passports and citizenship at Russian diplomatic missions in Ukraine. The bills are seen as a response to the strong pro-Russian and separatist sentiments in Ukraine's Crimea region, where many Russian citizens already reside.

The McLaren team, once a dominant force in Formula 1 with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a decline after a successful history that includes a 1988 season sweep and a 1998-99 victory with Mika Hakkinen. Despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton, in the cockpit, the team has faced scandals, including illegal possession of Ferrari technical information and misleading stewards. The current team boss, Ron Dennis, believes McLaren will return to success, but the team is currently struggling with issues related to the Honda power unit.

Tommy Baker, a 44-year-old from Everton, was shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool, leading to his death in hospital. Three men, aged 29, 29, and 32, have been arrested and are in police custody. The shooting occurred after Baker left Phoenix Gym, with suspects waiting outside for about an hour. Police are searching for a silver VW polo that fled the scene and are urging people who saw anything on CCTV to come forward.

The passage discusses various ways to celebrate Christmas online, including virtual church services, a fantasy game with Bible-themed quests, a unique nativity video, a Christmas ad, and a manga book about the nativity. These initiatives aim to make Christmas more accessible and engaging, especially for those who can't attend church or prefer digital experiences.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is examining a request to take over 250 hectares of common land, with Blaenau Gwent council offering 320 hectares as replacement land. Experts have conflicting views on the impact of the circuit on habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to conclude the replacement land's value but does not oppose the development overall. An ecology report suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity, but the Gwent wildlife trust disagrees. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, before the Welsh government ministers make the final decision.

On 3 April, Chechen Muslim clerics condemned a report by Novaya Gazeta, calling it an insult to their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, and called for retribution against the journalists. The report, published on 1 April, detailed the detention and alleged torture of over 100 people, including homosexuals, in Chechnya. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's accuracy, while Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor, Dmitry Muratov, defended the report, stating it was not intended to insult Chechens. The LGBT Network is assisting people to escape persecution in Chechnya and threatens to take the case to the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute the abuses.

Investing Solutions, a company that finds properties for single homeless men, has been criticized for its relationship with Fresh Start Housing, a charity that refers clients to both the company and private landlords. The company profits by charging housing benefit for each person living in a shared property, rather than the property itself, leading to higher benefit payouts than the rent paid to landlords. The company, which is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, has been accused of prioritizing profit over the well-being of its clients, with one tenant describing the properties as "wholly unsuitable." Despite these allegations, the company maintains that it works with private sector landlords and is concerned about the state of the properties. Fresh Start Housing, which houses 788 homeless people since its founding, has not disclosed how many are housed with Investing Solutions.

Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 in a well-contested game, with GB leading for most of the first three quarters before being overtaken in the last 10 minutes. The Dutch team, led by Worthy De Jong, won 71-60, despite GB's comeback in the final six minutes. Coach Joe Prunty praised Gordon's contribution, who joined the team despite missing out on a spot in the London 2012 Olympics. GB will now begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) is set to debate the use of 8oz gloves, instead of the standard 10oz, for a boxing match between Conor McGregor and Floyd Mayweather. McGregor, a former UFC lightweight champion, has submitted a waiver for the lighter gloves, which offer less cushioning but could result in more punishing punches. The NAC executive director, Bob Bennett, has studied McGregor's progress and believes there are several reasons to approve the fight. McGregor, who will make his boxing debut, has previously used 4oz gloves in the UFC and has been praised by boxing personalities for his skills. The NAC will make its decision publicly before the bout, which could be the richest fight in history. McGregor's team has also hired Hall of Fame boxing referee Joe Cortez to ensure they are comfortable with the rules.

Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, former journalists at the Sunday Post, reflect on the decline of Fleet Street, once a hub for British journalism, as the last two journalists are made redundant. Fleet Street, known for its bars, pubs, and the Daily Courant's first publication, was a significant source of public information before the rise of television and social media. The street's decline began with the move of media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's papers to Wapping in 1986, leading to the adoption of new technology and the eventual repurposing of the buildings. Sherriff and Smith, now freelance and writing memoirs, respectively, reminisce about the vibrant history of Fleet Street.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, expressed her belief in standing up to bullies after receiving abusive comments on Twitter. She donated £1m to the Labour party in 2008 and to the No vote campaign in the Scottish independence referendum, which led to criticism. Rowling revealed she had blocked some abusive Twitter users and had engaged in political discussions with some Scottish National Party (SNP) supporters. She also humorously responded to a suggestion to burn her books by saying she would bring marshmallows. The SNP won 56 out of 59 seats in the Scottish election, making it the third largest party in the UK.

The University of Edinburgh study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and are more likely to be involved in violent crime, with poverty increasing the likelihood of offending. The study also found that a history of police trouble was a strong predictor of young people not being in education, employment, or training by age 18. The study tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and was funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation, and the Scottish government. The Scottish government claims Scotland is becoming a safer place to live, with crime at a 41-year low, but a separate study suggests crime is still highly concentrated in poor communities.

Robbie Walsh, 25, was charged with assault causing serious harm after stabbing Mr. Haugh in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee, Ireland. Mr. Haugh was found dead at Limerick University Hospital. Two other men arrested in connection with the incident were released without charge. The case will be reviewed by the Director of Public Prosecutions.

Phil Flanagan, the Fermanagh MLA, tweeted in 2014 about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member, questioning his past actions. The tweet was later deleted, and Flanagan apologized, admitting his comments were untrue. The High Court heard that Flanagan's insurance firm refused to cover any compensation costs, and he is now challenging that decision. Tom Elliott, who served in the UDR between 1982 and 1992, is now the MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with a history dating back to 1874, has increased its sweater production to 9,500 per week to meet the demand from both private label clients and its own brand. The company, which employs over 230 staff, was bought by Benny Hartop in November of the previous year. The increase in production is a response to a surge in orders from home and abroad, and the company has seen growth in its longer-established business of supplying customers who sell the garments under their private labels. Hawick Knitwear sells into Europe and markets outside Europe, including the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright, a 55-year-old man, while crossing the road outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright, who was blinded by the setting sun, admitted to striking Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. He is currently on trial, with the court hearing that the sun was 10 minutes from setting and could have been shining into Wright's eyes. Blackburn is now being treated in residential care. Wright expressed remorse for his actions, stating he was in total shock and has since thought of nothing else but Blackburn and her family.

The passage describes a NATO exercise, "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at improving anti-submarine warfare capabilities in response to the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves a German U-boat, U33, attempting to evade detection by NATO warships while trying to attack the USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker. The exercise highlights the challenges of detecting submarines and the importance of training for potential real-world scenarios. It also underscores the growing concern over Russia's increasing military strength, particularly its submarine fleet, and the need for NATO to be prepared for such threats. The passage also points out the significant gap in the UK's defenses due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, which could be exploited by Russian submarines.

The United Nations officials are concerned that the violence in South Sudan, which has led to ethnic cleansing and potential genocide, has caused 340,000 people to flee to Uganda, surpassing the 200,000 who fled Syria in 2016. The violence, which began as a civil war between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, has now spread to Equatorians, who are also being targeted. Refugees, including children, are arriving in Uganda, where they are being provided with land and shelter by aid agencies. However, the influx is straining resources, and the UNHCR is urging international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to stop the violence.

McKenzie, a professional boxer since 2013, will face Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on 12 November at York Hall. McKenzie, son of former champion Clinton and trained by his uncle Duke McKenzie, has a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights.

The £33m investment will fund a new Bridgwater Community Hospital with 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities, replacing the outdated 1813 building. The project, part of a £330m NHS investment, will be paid for by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, with planning permission required for the Bowers Lane site. The new hospital aims to be completed by autumn 2014, offering a modern, one-stop care setting.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near Sheffield city centre, while driving a black Mercedes. He was found with a gunshot wound to his chest and taken to Northern General hospital, where he died. The victim was a family member attending a celebration when the shooting occurred. This incident is part of a series of shootings in Sheffield, with previous incidents occurring in the north of the city.

The passage discusses various pro-Ukrainian hacker groups, including the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International, who engage in cyber warfare against Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their DDoS attacks, hacking into servers, and monitoring public CCTV systems. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, targets Ukrainian government websites and claims to have hacked into US Vice-President Joe Biden's team. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin and focuses on Russia's domestic affairs. The passage also mentions the use of hacked information by Ukraine's security services, which is denied by officials.

Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, and Alex Salmond, all MSPs, bid farewell to the parliament as they stand down ahead of the election on May 5. Salmond, former first minister, emphasized Scotland's diversity and the need for greater parliamentary responsibility, while McNeil highlighted the need for accountability and learning from Westminster. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also announced her departure, joking about missing her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, will gather experiences from pensioners and their families in residential care to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. This is part of her review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. Rochira will consider factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. The review aims to ensure that those responsible for services understand the realities of living in residential care and the necessary changes to improve the quality of life for older people. The chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that a provider expert is not included on the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, a Turriff-based company, saw a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5m in the year to June 2016, despite a £1m fall in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors, also operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, offering products for farming and rural communities. The company remains confident in its position despite the uncertain impact of Brexit and challenging times in the agriculture industry.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, and a man in his 80s was taken to hospital. The police are treating the death as murder and are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker. McLoughlin is described as white, 6ft tall, with greying, collar-length hair, and of average build. He was believed to be wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked short-sleeved shirt with a button-down collar. The police are conducting additional patrols in the area and have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, IMF's second-in-command, warned of global economic risks in a speech, citing a weakening global economy and a potential downgrade of the global growth forecast from 3.4%. The IMF's concerns are heightened by China's weaker-than-expected trade figures, with exports dropping by a quarter from the previous year, impacting businesses and industries that relied on China's growth.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until 2 July to address issues with the new ferry, which has experienced problems since its launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, groundings, and training issues. A review of the project by auditors has been ordered, and compensation for local businesses affected by the ferry's issues is being discussed. Transport councillor Ian Ward described the situation as a prototype with expected teething problems, which have been partially resolved.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott at 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook for investigation.

Matching Models, an international temp agency, has faced criticism for its job advertisements, which have been described as "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women" by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC). The agency's ads, such as one for a personal assistant with a "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup," and another for a "sexy female driver" to drive a Porsche Cayenne, have been called discriminatory and potentially illegal. The EHRC and women's equality campaigners argue that these ads are outdated and violate equality legislation. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends the ads, stating that clients have specific requirements. The 2010 Equality Act prohibits discrimination based on various factors, including age, sexual orientation, and disability. Matching Models' clients include major companies like MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Coca-Cola.

A shooting at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore resulted in the death of 18-year-old Gautami and severe injuries to another student, Sirisha. The alleged shooter, Mahesh, was an office assistant at the school and was arrested after a manhunt. Incidents of gun crime at schools in India are rare, and the motive behind the shooting remains unclear. Mahesh was remanded until 12 April. India has strict control laws, but feuds are often settled with firearms. In 2007, a 14-year-old schoolboy was shot dead by two fellow students near Delhi.

Glaad's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 LGBT characters, with transgender characters increasing from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers alone don't tell the full story.

David Mackintosh, a Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced his decision to not seek re-election, following criticism and a police investigation into the disappearance of £10.25m loaned to Northampton Town FC, which he had previously helped to fund for stadium development.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fired a rifle into a car full of teenagers, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards, as they left a party in Balch Springs, Dallas. Oliver was later fired for policy violations and faces five to 99 years in prison for murder, potentially making him the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas county since 1973. The trial date has not been set.

The president-elect has not set a date for Mrs. Trump and Barron to move to Washington, D.C., but they will soon move after Barron finishes school. Transition spokesman Jason Miller stated the Trumps are excited about their new role, but this did not calm social media criticism. Some critics questioned Mrs. Trump's decision, while others speculated about its implications for the Trumps' marriage. Historically, only two First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Mrs. Trump's decision has supporters who believe it is responsible parenting. In the past, children of presidents have lived in the White House, but not always during their parents' terms. The Obamas moved early to avoid school changes for their daughters. Melania Trump has indicated Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on a full-time role like previous First Ladies. Mrs. Obama has been active in supporting causes, while Mrs. Reagan was more private. Ivanka Trump may take on some responsibilities, as Chelsea Clinton did during her father's presidency. The White House can be shaped by the family, and both Hillary Clinton and Michelle Obama managed their duties around their children.

The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to a call from a 72-year-old man who died in Inverness on 27 October. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed Pirc to undertake this investigation. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation. A report on the findings will be submitted to the COPFS.

A yellow warning was issued for wind gusts up to 75mph, particularly to the west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction expected to increase the impact. Travel disruptions on roads and at sea are likely, affecting counties including Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route, and Telford Road will remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants started with a short-handed opener from Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. Mike Forney scored a powerplay goal, making it 2-1, with Andy Bohmback equalizing. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2. Nottingham's David Ling equalized, and the teams will meet again in their double-header. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing, and made five pit stops, facing a 36-point deficit. Sebastian Vettel finished second after a collision with Kimi Raikkonen, who then moved up the field. Hamilton's car was damaged in a collision with Felipe Nasr, affecting his performance. Despite this, Hamilton expressed confidence in eroding Rosberg's points lead, though no driver who has won the first three races has failed to win the championship. The race featured numerous collisions, leading to the safety car's introduction. Rosberg took the lead from Nico Rosberg, who had a puncture, and Mercedes did not stop him under the safety car, allowing him to drive off into the distance. Hamilton struggled to recover, facing an uphill battle to stop Rosberg from winning his first world title.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, sparking praise from teammates, football figures, and the German Football Association. His announcement is seen as a significant step in addressing homophobia in football, with hopes that it will lead to greater openness about sexuality in the sport.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, helping Brighton secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring, Sidwell hopes to sign a new deal, expressing his desire to continue playing at the top level. He has previously played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, and believes he deserves another opportunity. Sidwell's performances have exceeded expectations, and he is optimistic about securing a new contract.

Blackpool and Colchester United played a closely contested match, ending 1-1. Nathan Delfouneso scored for Blackpool, and Kurtis Guthrie equalized for Colchester. Blackpool's Sam Slocombe made several key saves, while Colchester had a late red card for Sean Murray. The match saw numerous free kicks, corners, and substitutions, with both teams having opportunities to score. Blackpool's Tom Aldred and Colchester's Jordan Flores had notable moments, but neither could secure a win. The match ended with Blackpool leading 1-1, Colchester United 1-1.

The 29-year-old, with previous spells at Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for Colchester United last season, which was relegated from League One. He could debut for the U's in an EFL Cup first-round tie against Aston Villa. Colchester started the season with a 3-1 defeat at Accrington.

The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m for a permanent memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum to honor PC Keith Palmer and over 1,400 officers and staff who have lost their lives, with the government contributing £1m towards the £4m needed, and the memorial expected to be completed by 2019.

Manchester United, led by Ferguson, remains 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League table with eight games left after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. Ferguson emphasized the importance of focusing on upcoming matches, including the derby against Manchester City. Despite injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea, Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea. Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley did not start in the Sunderland match, and Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez are available for the upcoming Chelsea game. Ferguson praised Sunderland for their strong performance, crediting their win to determined defending and courage.

Mr Schmidt, CEO of Google, stated that the company pays legally required UK corporate taxes, and if tax laws change, Google will comply. He also called for a debate on international tax reform, while Margaret Hodge suggested a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements. The EU agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an automatic information exchange between tax authorities. Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland, has been criticized for minimizing UK tax payments. The Google chairman previously argued that corporate taxes should be levied where economic activity and risks are conducted, not where products are consumed. He also called for politicians to set the rules, not companies.

NHS Improvement, the regulator, is urging the NHS to make more progress in reducing the agency bill, which was £3.6bn last year. The regulator wants this reduced by £1bn by the end of the financial year, and a cap introduced in October has saved £600m. The cap limits hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services to paying no more than 55% above normal shift rates for staff, with only senior managers exempted. The aim is to reduce overall costs and reliance on agency staff, who are more expensive due to additional fees and employer costs. Despite progress, NHS Improvement finds the NHS still behind schedule, with trusts 10% off target. The regulator will publish league tables of the best and worst-performing trusts on agency spending later this year.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic boom, now reflects the country's economic downturn. Local traders, like Matt O'Brien, are seeing signs of recovery, with increased business and diversification into new areas. However, the Fianna Fáil party criticizes the government's investment decisions, arguing for a focus on broadband improvement instead of water meters. The government counters by highlighting the potential of a new tourism development by Center Parcs, which could employ 1,000 people. Despite these developments, traders believe more can be done to boost local business, such as addressing parking issues. Overall, the midlands are beginning to see economic recovery, but more efforts are needed.

The cricket tournament concludes on May 29 in the same stadium, featuring eight teams playing twice, with the top four qualifying for the play-offs. BBC Sport provides updates on scores, fixtures, and results. Notable players include Warner, Kohli, De Villiers, De Kock, McClenaghan, Kumar, and Rahman. Four current or former England players, Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen, participate. The fixtures span from April 25 to May 29, with a qualifier on May 24, an eliminator on May 27, and the final on May 29.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, which are often non-recyclable and contribute to environmental issues. In England, a 5p charge on plastic bags from October aims to reduce their use, following a successful decrease in other UK regions with similar charges.

A school roof was torn off at Rhosgadfan, Gwynedd, amid widespread power cuts, train delays, and travel disruptions across Wales due to high winds. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, and Irish Ferries cancelled six sailings, with festive events like Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip postponed.

The actor expressed excitement to work with director Ryan Coogler and stars Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman on a new film, following his role in the Fantastic Four reboot. Black Panther, featuring Boseman, is set for release in February 2018.

The theatre, founded in 1875, is part of a larger east wing restoration project to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination. The project, which includes repairing and refurbishing the BBC studios, aims to reopen the theatre in 2018. The Heritage Lottery Fund and Haringey Council are contributing £18.8m and £6.8m respectively, with Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust raising the final £1m. The theatre, which still retains much of its original decor and stage machinery, was created to showcase various forms of entertainment, including opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema screenings.

The former Manchester City player, 30, has won 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009, including appearances at two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played three minutes at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, and scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her daughter escaped their house in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, which was destroyed by a fire caused by rubbish burned in the wood stove. Their dog and cats perished. David, their son, was the only one awake and alerted them to the fire, which had already consumed the kitchen. The family, wearing only pyjamas, received community support in the form of clothing, shoes, and a bike for David. Mrs. Smith expressed immense pride in her son's actions and plans to remind him of his bravery for the rest of his life.

The energy drinks giant is reportedly considering a £200m offer for Premier League club West Ham, which Sullivan and Gold, who own more than 85% of the club, bought in 2010 for £105m. West Ham has been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups, and Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but the ownership is intended to pass to their children.

Jillian Bell, Shailene Woodley, Bradley Cooper, Channing Tatum, Meryl Streep, Kevin Hart, Robert Downey Jr, Scarlett Johansson, Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, Mark Ruffalo, and Jeremy Renner were among the winners at the Oscars, which also served as a promotional platform for upcoming blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars won best movie, while Woodley won best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Cooper won best male performance, Tatum won best comedic performance, Streep won best villain, and Hart won comedic genius award. Downey Jr won the Generation Award, and clips from upcoming films were shown.

Dons loaned Smith, 21, to United, where he has scored five goals this season. Smith, who made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, has scored four times in 89 appearances for Aberdeen. St Mirren's boss, Jack Ross, praised Smith as a "brilliant acquisition" and a "good, mature boy" who will be a good fit for the team. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.
Northumberland County Council plans to use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily for the next four months, with additional staff repairing drainage systems and clearing gutter debris.

In December 2016, six Wood Group employees working on EnQuests's Thistle platform in Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during shutdown work. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes reported that the workers were not provided with proper personal protective equipment (PPE) and faced cancer fears, with ongoing blood tests. EnQuest stated that additional precautionary steps had been taken, and a joint investigation with Wood Group was conducted. The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) was informed but deemed the incident not reportable under the current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007 for $650,000 (£420,000). The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. The decision to return the sculpture came after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The ASI submitted an official request for the return of the sculpture in May. ACM's manager, Aaron Freedman, later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the sculpture. ACM plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck 15.5km deep near Lucca, Italy, felt as far as Milan and Florence, with no immediate injuries or damage reported. The quake, which occurred at 15:48, caused power outages and phone line disruptions in the Garfagnana area, leading to school evacuations. The region has a history of seismic activity, including a deadly 2009 quake in L'Aquila. The latest tremor was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow." The National Institute of Geophysics and Volcanology (INGV) noted several aftershocks. The area had previously experienced two deadly earthquakes in May, with the strongest being magnitude-6. Six scientists and an ex-official were convicted in 2012 for providing false reassurances about the risk of a major earthquake in 2009, which led to many deaths.

Austin Grant from Sheffield, initially skeptical about South Yorkshire's climate, is now excited after seeing positive results in his fruit harvest, with the fruit still attached to the plant and not yet ripe for consumption.

Rockstar has delayed the release of their open world adventure game, originally scheduled for 27 January, until 24 March, citing the need for additional testing and polishing. The company assures fans that the extra time will enhance the game's quality. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release, and detailed screenshots of the PC version have been released, promising high-resolution visuals. The minimum PC specifications for GTA V have also been published. The game, which became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generated $1bn in just three days upon its 2013 release.

The 76-year-old artist, who won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery, was one of the shortlisted artists in 1991. The painting, depicting a leper squint, was described as "quite extraordinary" by judge Ansel Krut. The artist, Simpson, has been shortlisted three times before and plans to use the prize money to purchase materials for his work. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig. Sir Peter Blake, the current patron, won the junior title in 1961.

The Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit offices were attacked by four masked assailants, with no casualties reported. Firefighters extinguished the blaze, and police have cordoned off the area. Both papers support the AK Party of President Erdogan, and the attacks occurred simultaneously early on Thursday. Windows were shattered, and numerous spent bullet casings were found. No group has claimed responsibility, and police are searching for the assailants. The Yeni Akit offices are 20km away from the Yeni Safak building.

A 24-year-old player, Marcus Bignot, who was under contract with the Stags, has been brought in on a free transfer by the Stags' side. He previously spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. He will officially join the Stags on 1 January, making him Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger has been linked with the England national team job, which former England international manager Sam Allardyce left in September. Wenger, who is currently contracted until the summer, has expressed his focus on his current role and believes in the importance of competency over big names. He also mentioned that 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin will be offered a new contract by Arsenal, despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey is expected to miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker at approximately 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police are conducting a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, and the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve a dispute over seafarers' pay, with contracted services returning to Serco Northlink from next month. The RMT union had claimed some workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour, but Serco Northlink had offered to bridge the pay gap. The new arrangements will ensure all crew members are paid at least the minimum wage, and the charter change will come into force early next month. Serco Northlink operates three ferries and two cargo boats to the Northern Isles on a heavily subsidised route.

Ken Dickie, 64, died after intervening in an argument with his mother, Jamie Mitchell, 35, who admitted to common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice. The incident occurred at Rockley Park in Poole, and the couple had been going through a difficult period in their relationship. They had initially lied to the police about the events leading to Mr. Dickie's death. The court will sentence them on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter known for hits like "Rock With You," "Thriller," and "Baby Be Mine," passed away at 66 after a battle with cancer. He was a key contributor to Michael Jackson's music, writing for his solo albums and the soundtrack for "The Color Purple," and won a Grammy for his work on Quincy Jones's album "Back on the Block." His songwriting legacy includes collaborations with artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, and Chaka Khan.

A team of researchers, including Swansea University's Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, discovered ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. The team, which also includes researchers from Exeter, Reading, and SÃ£o Paulo, BelÃ£m universities, found over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest. The function of these sites is still not fully understood, but they are thought to have been used sporadically, perhaps as ritual gathering places. Dr Loader's analysis of soil samples, phytoliths, charcoal, and carbon stable isotopes suggests the geoglyphs were constructed amongst taller vegetation, not visible above the forest canopy. The research indicates that humans artificially brought together a variety of plant species over 6,000 years, transforming their environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees. The team likens this to a form of "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products, and suggests that the biodiversity of some of Acre's remaining forests may retain a strong legacy of these ancient "agroforestry" practices.

Australian tennis player Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of a tournament. He won the Japan Open and is nearing the top 10. Kyrgios mentioned feeling tired and bored during the match, attributing it to lack of sleep and the travel to the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai. He also recalled being fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst at the Shanghai Masters last year.

The HPV jab, which protects against head and neck cancers, is being advocated for by scientists and charities, including Tenovus Cancer Care and Cardiff University's HPV research team, to the Welsh government. They argue that the number of head and neck cancer cases is increasing, with younger, non-smoking men being affected. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any changes to the HPV vaccination programme.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old student from West Calder High School, was diagnosed with gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, a rare form of blood cancer. He documented his journey on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, which garnered over 28,000 likes. Despite his illness, Jak attended a school prom, where he was greeted by former Rangers captain Barry Ferguson. He was also awarded the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. Jak's cancer had spread throughout his body, and he passed away on 23 January. His family urged people to donate to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and a fundraising football match was planned for Sunday.

In a match with few chances, Egypt's Mohamed Salah assisted Abdallah El Said to score a late goal, securing a 1-0 victory over Uganda. The win keeps Egypt in contention for Group D's top spot, while Uganda, who haven't won a tournament since 1978, now face Mali in the final round. The match saw several offside calls, disallowed goals, and substitutions, with Egypt's goalkeeper Essam El Hadary and goalkeeper Ahmed Fathy both making crucial saves. The game ended with Egypt 1, Uganda 0.

Lancashire County Council plans to use land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College, which are currently unused, for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, a town in the north west of England without its own station. The new station, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, will provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The council will begin acquiring the necessary land for the project.
The police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house during a warehouse search near Ashbourne, and a man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old German woman of Kurdish origin was found with serious injuries in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged by the neck through several streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man of Kurdish origin from Bad Muender, later surrendered to authorities. The motive for the attack is unclear, and the area has been secured with a call for witnesses. The woman underwent an emergency operation and was flown to a specialist clinic.

The research by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, which examined 4,600 workers, found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise, but are less likely to receive one. The study, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, ruled out the "reticent female" theory and found no evidence that women are more cautious about asking for a raise due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a female stereotype. The study also noted that men were 25% more likely to get a pay rise when they asked, and that there were no differences in pay rise rates between women and men under 40, suggesting a shift in negotiating behavior among younger women.

Oxford City Council has been unable to find a suitable new burial site for many years, despite using funds for ground investigations. Two cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, still have space, but are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. The council is still exploring options, but has ruled out the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, will offer an augmented reality app for visitors to access online information from signs and posters, view videos and band interviews, and interact with the festival from anywhere. The festival will feature acts like The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The app will also allow people to access information, buy tickets, and experience the festival's unique atmosphere.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, despite having no significant underlying health issues. The horse suffered from a rare "severe pulmonary haemorrhage". Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had never collapsed before. Questions have been raised about whether his tendency to 'overheat' was linked to his death, but the report concludes it was due to the haemorrhage.

A 15-year-old girl reported being raped by Davina, a 34-year-old man, in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Davina, who has learning difficulties and changed her name in 2012, denied the charge. She was remanded into custody and likely to be held in a male prison in Winchester, as she was considered a risk to herself and others. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of Foster's, clearly remembered the event and reported it to a care home worker in 2014. Davina spoke about her sexuality during the trial, but made no physical changes or took medication. The court heard that Davina attempted suicide the previous summer. Davina will be sentenced on 4 March.

The Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, following Djokovic's defeat by Juan Martin del Potro, and Djokovic's previous loss at Wimbledon to Sam Querrey, before Djokovic won his 30th Masters title in Toronto.

Over 20 competitors from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, are set to participate in a log carving event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms. Carvers use only chainsaws to create animal and human shapes from logs. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old rugby player, is close to returning to the field after a serious foot injury. He is currently in a pre-season stage and plans to take each week as it comes. Webb, who has been capped 16 times by Wales, has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from elsewhere. He will begin the Six Nations campaign away to Ireland on February 7.

On Tuesday, US border agents intercepted two men attempting to smuggle MDMA from Canada to San Francisco, with one man firing a weapon and escaping. A third man, Nathan Hall, and a woman, Kali Henifin, were arrested for their roles in the smuggling operation, which involved a total of 58lb of ecstasy. The suspects face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported counseling over 4,500 children in the past year, a significant increase from 2,400 in 2011-12, for online abuse, with some children as young as seven affected. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, emphasized the need for adult intervention to protect children from cyber-bullying, which can follow them home and worsen if left unaddressed. The report coincides with Anti-Bullying Week, and the Anti Bullying Alliance is collaborating with various groups to tackle the issue. A young person shared their experience of being told to kill themselves by online peers, highlighting the emotional impact and the difficulty in seeking help.

The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, which infuriated Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The resolution, which passed on Friday, deemed the establishment of settlements as illegal and a major obstacle to peace. In response, Netanyahu recalled Israel's ambassadors to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal, and cancelled a visit by Ukraine's prime minister. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorizing new homes in settlements, at the request of Netanyahu's office, to avoid straining relations with Washington ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Kerry is expected to address "misleading critiques" of the Obama administration by the Israeli government and outline his vision for ending the conflict. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas sees the resolution as paving the way for the upcoming Middle East peace conference in France.

In a BBC interview, Prince William praised Queen Elizabeth II as a "guiding example" of a good monarch, while also addressing criticisms of his own commitment to royal duties. The Queen's 90th birthday was marked with various events, including a visit to Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office, a ceremony to open a new bandstand, and a series of stamps released to celebrate her milestone. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their well-wishes, and the Queen and Prince Philip will unveil a plaque and light a beacon to mark the occasion. The BBC faced criticism for its extensive coverage of the Queen's birthday.

West Ham United dominated Cheltenham Town in a League Two match, scoring two quick goals in the first half from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew, and maintaining control until the final whistle. Despite Cheltenham's efforts, including a notable volley from Harry Pell, they were unable to score. The match ended 2-0 in favor of West Ham United, with Cheltenham Town making several changes to their lineup following losses in the Premier League. The game also marked the end of League Two's representation in the EFL Cup. Key moments included a missed opportunity by Cheltenham's James Collins and a strong performance by West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian. West Ham's Slaven Bilic's side could have won by a greater margin, but Cheltenham's Kyle Storer cleared a header off the line, and keeper Jonathan Flatt saved a cross from Sakho. The match concluded with Cheltenham Town's exit and West Ham United's victory.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a car accident caused by Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig, who failed to see a motorcyclist while turning his car. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner to be jailed, and Werner expressed remorse but could not explain the accident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, London, is facing a possible life imprisonment sentence for his role in Syria. He was a prominent British fighter in Syria, known for his online presence and masked appearances. Khawaja, who called himself Abu Daigham al-Britani, was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State. He was involved in fundraising, video diaries, and tours of fighters' quarters. Khawaja's return to the UK was facilitated by his cousin Tahir Bhatti, who admitted to assisting an offender. Khawaja had faked his own death and attempted to re-enter the UK unnoticed. He is currently held in the special unit for high-risk terrorism suspects at London's Belmarsh prison. Khawaja has admitted four offences, and an additional charge of soliciting to murder will remain on file.

Jackson, a 22-year-old footballer, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, helping the team finish eighth in the table. He is Barnsley's third signing for the next season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley. Jackson declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the upcoming season. Barnsley's caretaker boss, Paul Heckingbottom, praised Jackson's pace and defensive skills. For more football transfers, visit the dedicated page.

National Trust volunteers are clearing away bottles that have washed up on Poldhu Cove, Lizard, as they pose a risk to wildlife. The bottles, believed to have come from a ship's container lost during a storm, are sealed but some have leaked. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there is no evidence linking the bottles to the MV Blue Ocean's lost container. Other nearby coves are also affected. Cornwall Wildlife Trust and the National Trust are concerned about the impact on marine life, and the public is advised to keep a safe distance from the bottles.

A car crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at around 14:00, resulting in minor injuries to several people. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is conducting ongoing inquiries into the incident.

Dervite, a French centre-back, made 14 appearances for Wanderers last season, helping them finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in all competitions. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution towards the end of the campaign. Dervite is among several players, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan, who have signed new contracts with Bolton following their promotion to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of being willing to "concede everything", while Labour's Baroness Smith accused the Lib Dems of giving "false hope". The two parties had previously collaborated to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval, but this cooperation ended when MPs rejected amendments, with Lib Dems insisting on them and Labour deferring to the Commons. A Labour source criticized the Lib Dems' actions as "unforgiveable" and "grandstanding", while the Lib Dems' Europe spokesperson accused Labour of supporting the government's hard Brexit plans. Despite past alliances on various issues, a Labour source predicted "residual tensions" and little demand for a "progressive consensus summer drinks" gathering.

In the current election, defence is a low priority for most political parties, with public opinion polls showing it ranks behind the economy, NHS, and immigration. UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya have contributed to public and political reluctance to focus on defence. The UK's defence spending has fallen, and there are concerns about future cuts, with the MoD's budget being the second largest non-protected budget. The Conservatives, UKIP, and the SNP have differing views on the UK's nuclear deterrent, with potential implications for defence spending. The Royal Navy's plans for new aircraft carriers, the Queen Elizabeth and the Prince of Wales, are also under scrutiny due to potential staffing and equipment issues.

The Spanish football club Barcelona is under investigation for potentially misappropriating money during the transfer of Neymar, with the club insisting they have not committed any offence. The club has paid a total of £106.8m for Neymar, including fees, wages, and taxes, and has made a tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros. The case will continue to be investigated, and there has not yet been any confirmation whether the case will be dropped after Barcelona's payment. Neymar has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and netted three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was a passenger in a van hit by a Mazda Premacy driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. The incident occurred on the motorway near Kegworth, Leicestershire, at 02:00 GMT on 12 October. Luciw's family, including his mother Andrea Shelton, called for regular driving tests for older people, while Age UK emphasized the importance of older people retaining their driving privileges. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) stated that there is no evidence older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents, and they maintain a self-assessment form for drivers over 70 to renew their licenses every three years.

The independent review of transvaginal mesh implants, which are used to treat incontinence, concluded that the procedures should not be offered routinely to women with pelvic organ prolapse. Instead, patients should be given a range of treatment options and the information to make informed choices. The report also recommended mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the government stated it could not ban the procedures, as that power lies with the Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency. The review faced criticism for not achieving consensus, with some panel members resigning in protest. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh implants, with more than 400 currently taking legal action due to complications.

Muir, a 23-year-old runner, broke McColgan's 25-year-old British 1500m record by 14 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow, with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds. McColgan, who had concerns about the race meeting UK Athletics' criteria for record-breaking attempts, confirmed that Muir's time was expected to be ratified as official. McColgan praised Muir's potential, noting her ability to reach 14.30 in a 5K, and compared Muir's race to her own record-breaking race 25 years ago. Muir also broke her own British 1500m record at the Diamond League meeting in Paris in August and reached the 1,500m Olympic final at Rio 2016.

Jung won the event aboard Sam, replacing Fischertakinou who fell ill. France's Astier Nicolas took silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. GB's William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, 10 months after a coma from a fall, and had a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase. However, his medal bid was ruined by a poor performance in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also mentions a special guide to meet and ride Henry the mechanical horse at Official Team GB fan parks during the Rio Olympics.

Andy Murray defeated Italian player Fognini in a five-set match, with Murray winning 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, 6-1. Murray, the 11th time a finalist, will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Murray's win was marked by a tense fourth set, with Fognini showing both talent and temperamental sides. Murray's victory was celebrated by the 15,000 spectators on Centre Court. Murray expressed satisfaction with his performance and plans to work on his game before his next match.

Paramedics attended a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven, Limavady, at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014. Police found several people at the bar, which served alcohol until 04:49 BST. The bar was ordered to close for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. O'Neill, who had a poor record, was fined £3,000, while Thomas was fined £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, launching the Ulster Unionists' manifesto, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination, while also addressing the Renewable Heat Incentive issue. He defended his comments about potentially transferring to the SDLP, stating he would not change his words and is confident in his position. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', includes calls for action on various issues, including tackling waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, standing up for the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is worse off due to Brexit. The party also calls for cleaning up Stormont, highlighting incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, confirmed a motion to the assembly for approval, which will align Northern Ireland with England and Wales in granting automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', the law will also allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion will allow pardons both posthumously and for living gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion to pardon convictions related to abolished sexual offences. The motion will now go forward for consideration by the assembly.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old veterinary student from Kinross, finished second in a race, beating Yvonne Murray's 1994 Scottish record and moving to second on the British all-time list. Muir, who also holds the Scottish 1500m and mile records, expressed her satisfaction with the Scottish record and her excitement about coming close to Faith Kipyegon. Muir hopes to secure an Olympic place for Great Britain in Rio at the British trials in Birmingham. She started her season with an 800m victory in Montbeliard, France, and will compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir's husband, Tom Mooney, congratulated her on Facebook.
The passage highlights a selection of photographs from 26 beaches in Scotland that have been rated as "most excellent" for water quality.

Richard Horwell QC, a Met Police barrister, stated that Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, the suspects in the poisoning of former KGB officer Alexander Litvinenko, had no personal motive to kill him. He suggested that the Russian state was likely involved in the plot, as it had reasons to want Litvinenko dead. Horwell emphasized that the involvement of the Russian state did not necessarily implicate President Vladimir Putin. Litvinenko died after drinking tea containing polonium-210, a radioactive substance, during a meeting with Kovtun and Lugovoi. Horwell also mentioned that Litvinenko had been poisoned twice before his death and that the risk to the public from polonium radiation is unknown. The suspects remain in Russia, and attempts to extradite them have failed. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, will lead the one-day side and captain the Twenty20 team for Australia, with David Warner, 28, as his vice-captain. Rod Marsh, the national selector, praised Smith's talent and leadership potential. Clarke, 34, has decided to retire after a heavy defeat by England in the Ashes, making Smith the new captain. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, has been chosen as vice-captain due to his maturity and development. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in the limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval on 20 August.

The passage discusses a political figure's stance on LGBT rights, including his refusal to directly answer whether he believes homosexual sex is a sin, his support for equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender people, and his opposition to the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties.

Sanofi closed its drug manufacturing site in Fawdon in 2015, leading to 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare plans to use the site for pharmaceutical production, potentially rehiring ex-Sanofi staff, which is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy. The move is seen as a boost to Newcastle's reputation as a science and healthcare hub, with Accord Healthcare being a global pharmaceutical player.

Richard Ellis is leaving the local authority at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are going under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, the leader of the opposition SNP group, criticized the departures as indicative of the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects more to leave in the coming months. Ellis, Monaghan, and Sutherland have held significant roles within the council, and Angela Scott, the council chief executive, thanked them for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, Martin, experienced a crash at this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. He initially announced his retirement from road racing but later clarified that he still intends to race, though not on Hondas. Martin did not participate in the North West 200 due to a teammate's crash and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. He expressed dissatisfaction with the TT and felt he was used as a test rider. After further testing, Martin was informed by his team that the bike would not be competitive in Ulster, leading to his withdrawal. Martin is now focused on racing classics and unique events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC's leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost key northern states and control of Adamawa, but held on to Rivers State. The APC made historic gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP doing well only in the south-east and Niger Delta. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP will need to go through a period of introspection and rebuild under a new leader.

A US-based environmental group, Mighty, has accused an agricultural commodities trader, Olam, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, of ignoring unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to haze in Southeast Asia. Olam, which sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, has a "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" policy and only recently released the names of its 14 suppliers. Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, has dismissed the allegations, stating it does not direct Olam's business operations. The palm oil industry, worth $88bn by 2022, is often accused of deforestation, illegal labor practices, and environmental harm. Olam also faces accusations of contributing to deforestation in Gabon, but claims its partnerships with the Gabonese government are responsible and transparent.
A restaurant started serving puppy platters following a new law permitting dogs to eat at restaurants, provided they are outdoors.

Forward Fernando Forestieri is doubtful due to a knee issue, Derby County striker David Nugent is expected to return after a groin injury, and Midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall after scoring a late leveller in a recent game.

The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) lifted the ban on YouTube, stating that Google, the owner of YouTube, had launched a Pakistan-specific version. The ban, imposed in 2012, was due to the controversial US-made film Innocence of Muslims, which led to widespread protests in Pakistan. While the ban was lifted, some activists demand more transparency in the deal between Google and the government. Google has stated that it will remove content that violates its community guidelines and may restrict access to videos deemed illegal in Pakistan after a thorough review. The company also records government requests for content removal in its Transparency Report. Google has also launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian like Gianni Infantino, a presidential candidate, leading to concerns about a conflict of interest. LFA boss Musa Bility has threatened to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace long-standing president Sepp Blatter is in 18 days, with five candidates including Infantino, Prince Ali of Jordan, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale. Bility has questioned why Scala did not withdraw from the 2015 elections, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which bars committee members with conflicts of interest. Scala's spokesman, Andreas Bantel, disagrees, stating there is no such provision in FIFA's regulations. Bility has also expressed his desire to participate in the elections, which will be held in Zurich.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road while working in a paint-spraying area.
